But it would be remiss to omit cryptocurrencies from an article on regulation. Indeed, there is still a general lack of consensus on whether cryptocurrencies should be deemed a proxy for money, commodities or an entirely new asset class altogether.

As the most popular of its peer group, bitcoin's share price rose stratospherically last year. At its peak, on 16 December, one bitcoin was worth around $19,000, a figure at least in part down to its lack of regulation, and representation of a decentralised, peer-to-peer traded medium of exchange (albeit one prone to serious volatility).

Cryptocurrencies have generally fared less well this year; the price of bitcoin fell below $7,000 on 5 February. This decline both drove, and was driven by, governments turning up the volume on their concerns about virtual cash, highlighting its danger to inexperienced investors and emphasising the need to crack down before it threatens financial systems.

Various economic leaders see the G20 summit, taking place later this month, as an opportunity to discuss worldwide crypto-regulation. The head of the Bank of International Settlements, AgustínCarstens, has been particularly vehement about the importance of asserting control. "Novel technology is not the same as better technology or better economics," he said. Bitcoin "has become a combination of a bubble, a Ponzi scheme and an environmental disaster" - the latter point referring to the amount of electricity used to "mine" new coins.

Moreover, one of the greatest concerns about cryptocurrency is its anonymity, rendering its origins - and potential facilitation of crime - difficult to trace.

Some countries and institutions are already taking restrictive steps. Among them, China is banning all domestic and foreign cryptocurrency trading platforms, and 'initial coin offerings' (ICOs) - the way in which companies raise digital money. South Korea will allow trading only via real-name bank accounts. Meanwhile, US banks including JPMorgan (US:JPM) and Citigroup (US:CITI), and Lloyds (LLOY) in the UK, have blocked cryptocurrency purchases on credit cards.

But for all Bitcoin's risks, advocates clearly perceive benefits beyond historic price appreciation. Some may liken it to gold, deeming it a 'safe haven' asset that could help to diversify a portfolio. It also enables immediate payments, while normal transactions can take longer. Most importantly, blockchain - the technology underpinning cryptocurrencies - has been hailed as world-changing. By providing a distributed ledger of transactions or records, blockchain could improve the way that data is registered and shared securely across multiple industries in future. That said, it is questionable whether buying bitcoin really represents an investment in blockchain.

The G20 summit could inspire a global regulatory framework for cryptocurrencies. As with many regulations in 2018, authorities will seek a compromise between preventing irresponsible practices and encouraging innovation. A regulated environment might lead more crypto-related businesses to consider an IPO, rather than the legally ill-defined 'initial coin offering'. For better or for worse, there's already hype among retail investors: last October, shares in minnow Aim company On-line (ONLY) soared simply on the news it would incorporate 'blockchain' into its name. The investor George Soros fears conglomerates, particularly in the tech space, could facilitate "totalitarian control the likes of which not even Aldous Huxley or George Orwell could have imagined". In 1984, Big Brother was always watching. In 2018, Big Brother's name is Alexa.

And it is not just their dominance which has critics worried. US tech firms have been accused of being anti-competitive and stifling fair trade. Amazon is a retailer and a marketplace. Google makes money by publishing content while determining the position of that content on its own search engine. Facebook doesn't need to make money from WhatsApp and Instagram because its newsfeed shares a duopoly in the digital advertising market with Google.

In the past few decades these companies and their peers have tiptoed from start-ups to corporate behemoths. Their growth has been largely organic, they have mainly made small acquisitions and they have refrained from engaging in mega-mergers. By and large, they have avoided the critical eye of competition laws.

US corporate antitrust law is governed by three statutes that are more than a century old. They restrict the formation of cartels which could hold back trade, limit M&A and prevent the creation of monopolies. And yet today in America a handful of companies control the same proportion of their respective markets as Standard Oil did when it was chopped up in 1911.

For years, these companies have been heralded as pioneers of digital America. But now - with Amazon raising the price of its books, Google increasingly embroiled in unsavoury ad campaigns, and Facebook facing calls to prevent interference on its platform by nation states - regulators have had enough. In 2017, the European Commission fined Google (EURO)2.4bn (£2.14bn) for prioritising its own shopping site. Germany's cartel office accused Facebook of unfairly using its position to track internet users. France has threatened to fine Facebook for sharing data between its apps. Australia's competition authority has launched an investigation into the market power of Facebook and Google. And even former US antitrust officials acknowledge that their approval of Google's acquisition of YouTube and Facebook's acquisition of Instagramlooks naive in hindsight.

Dealing with tech dominance is no mean feat. As former US federal judge Richard Posner wrote, about an earlier chapter in the internet revolution: "This problem will be extremely difficult to solve; indeed, I cannot even glimpse the solution." The difficulties lie in the fact that antitrust laws exist not to protect small businesses but to maximise consumer welfare, or what Robert Bork in 1978 dubbed "the antitrust paradox". Forty years on and Mr Bork's theory is starting to bite. Companies that try to team up to take on the might of the FANGs (Facebook, Amazon, Netflix (US:NFLX) and Google) are being regulated, while the giants can keep growing.

To avoid the dystopian future predicted by Mr Soros, global governments perhaps need a fundamental rethink of competition laws. After all, the world has changed a lot since the existent antitrust statutes were inscribed.

The 100-year-old US anti-trust laws are not going to be rewritten in 2018, but the fact that they are even being talked about should arouse concern for big tech monopolies. In the short-term FANG company shareholders should perhaps be wary that their uncontested days are coming to an end. The debate is also relevant for investors in the wider marketplace, as the rise in monopolistic corporate power may be an important factor behind elevated levels of profitability. That means changes in antitrust laws could have a real, albeit slow, impact on equitymarket returns.MB More regulations can be expected in due course. IFRS 16, governing how companies recognise and measure leases, will be introduced in 2019. Regulation around advertising is also high on the international agenda. Arguably, as technology comes to underpin every industry, those regulating each sector will need to work hand in glove to prevent dangerous scenarios - all the while encouraging innovation. Ten years ago, we endured the global financial crisis. Today, perhaps, we must try to stave offa global technology crisis.

7) DOMESTIC GAS AND ELECTRICITY (TARIFF CAP) ACT 2018 Date: Possibly the end of 2018 Sectors affected: Energy suppliers For years, regulation of the UK's energy supply market has oscillated between two driving principles. The first was that customers would be best served by measures to improve competition. The second - that it would be better to restrict pricing. Limited steps have been taken in both directions with the introduction of a price cap for prepayment meters and efforts to make switching to a new supplier easier, but in recent months political pressure from both sides of the aisle has meant suppliers are once again looking at a cap on the prices they can charge their customers.

The Domestic Gas and Electricity (Tariff Cap) Act 2018 was introduced in October last year and temporarily limits the amount that can be charged to consumers on the standard variable tariff (SVT). The cap level itself will be set by Ofgem, the market regulator, and will last until at least the end of 2020, with the potential for extension out to 2023. In February, MPs from the business, energy and industrial strategy select committee called for the cap to be brought into effect in time for the end of 2018, so as to protect vulnerable customers during the winter months. Analysts at RBC Capital Markets described this as "an ambitious target".

The energy suppliers have already started to look at ways to prevent or minimise the damage of any cap. Centrica (CNA) led the charge late last year with a raft of proposals both for how it would reform (eg by withdrawing the SVT for new customers) and how the government should adapt (eg by funding renewable subsidies through general taxation rather than through bills, as it is currently). SSE (SSE) took a different approach, proposing to demerge from its household energy supply business, combining it with rival NPower and listing it as a new company, thereby exiting the market.

There is a real possibility the cap will not come into effect until 2019, meaning it could potentially last less than two years. Despite this, the impact of this legislation is already being felt, as the share prices of Centrica and SSE demonstrate. Both can be expected to suffer once a cap is in place, unless SSE manages to leave the household supply market as it plans to. Approach the sector with caution. TD

urn:contentItem:5SHB-4271-JBJ7-N43R-00000-00Playing it nice: Apple is close to making history ... again2018-06-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:45ZLexisNexisPlaying it nice: Apple is close to making history ... againJohn McDuling

Apple is winning the race to become the world's first trillion dollar company. This week it revealed what might get it over the finish line.

In the race to become the world's first trillion dollar company, Apple has a healthy lead. And this week the company, which has a dominant position in Australia's smartphone and wearable device markets, revealed what might get it over the finish line.

To some extent, it is the opposite of what you might expect.

"It is interesting to hear a company say 'we want to limit use of our product'," Claire d'Este, a Hobart-based software engineer from Savage Interactive, told Fairfax Media this week on the sidelines of an Apple event in California. "It takes confidence to do that."

At its annual Worldwide Developer Conference in San Jose this week, Apple unveiled new tools to help people use iPhones less frequently than they currently do. It also announced new measures to block social media companies from tracking and building profiles on its users as they surf the internet.

In doing so, it directly addressed two of the biggest concerns swirling around the tech industry at the moment; and disarmed its biggest critics within the investment community, who have taken aim at the company on ethical grounds.

Apple has also pitted itself directly against Facebook and Google in a fierce ideological battle over privacy - and for the soul of the internet.

WWDC, Apple's biggest event of the year, is designed for developers, like d'Este, who helps build Procreate, a digital illustration app for the iPad. About 5000 'devs' like her made the trek to Northern California for the event this week.

Yet one of Apple's other constituencies - its investors - appear to be the week's big winners.

Apple shares climbed to fresh highs as WWDC took place, pushing its market value to within a smidgen of the arbitrary yet still historic $US1 trillion mark ($1.3 trillion). In comparison, Facebook is worth about $US560 billion and Google $US784 billion.

That is to say, the company's new initiatives were well received by Wall Street. "Apple is clearly committed to the idea that it is different from its competitors in terms of its outlook on privacy and user 'wellness'", wrote Macquarie analyst Ben Schachter.

Rival consumer tech companies are no doubt less thrilled by the week's proceedings.

Arguably the most striking development week was Apple's barely disguised disdain for Facebook, and what it sees as a cavalier approach to privacy from the social media behemoth.

In its keynote presentation this week, Apple made a string of not so subtle references to Facebook, which has been beset by another series of privacy crises this week.

As attendees entered the hall for the keynote address, they were greeted, as is custom, with a "wall of apps" emblazoned over big giant screens. The wall pointedly excluded Facebook - the most popular free app on smartphones in the world.

Later, Apple unveiled ScreenTime, its new feature that will help users (and parents) monitor usage of the iPhones and the apps that run on them. "Some apps demand more of our attention than we even realise," Craig Federighi, Apple's top engineering executive said at the conference. "It's become such a habit we might not even realise how distracted we have become."

The example of an app that can now be tracked and monitored Apple chose to use? Instagram - owned by Facebook.

Then Apple unveiled new features in the Safari browser that will block ad-tech companies from tracking users, building detailed profiles of them, and serving them creepy ads as they surf the internet.

Social media sharing buttons and comment fields could be used by such companies to collect data, Apple claimed. "We're shutting that down," Federighi said.

Again, the example Apple chose to use as a site that does that type of thing, which could now be stopped, was instructive: Facebook.com.

The rise, fall and resurgence of Apple

The rise of Apple under Steve Jobs in the 1980s, fall of the company in the 90s when he was ousted, and its resurgence upon his return in the 2000s, has been (very) well documented

It was Jobs' unyielding vision for the iPhone that propelled Apple into the corporate stratosphere. Less discussed is the role the software on those devices - made both by the company and by third party developers - played in that journey.

The App Store, which will turn 10 next month, has become one of Apple's most effective strategic weapons, and a lucrative earner for both the company and hordes of other companies building apps for it. Macqaurie described it as "the single most important driver of growth" in Apple's services revenue over the past decade.

"In those 10 years, the App Store has fundamentally changed the way we all live," Tim Cook, Apple's CEO and Jobs' successor, declared at WWDC this week. "It's enabled countless new companies, it's created tens of millions of new jobs, and spawned entirely new industries."

Third party developers, around 5000 of whom made the trek to San Jose this week, including d'Este, have now generated more than $US100 billion in earnings from the App Store over that period, he claimed.

That works out to be about $US14 billion annually in revenue for Apple from the App Store, according to Goldman Sachs. (Apple takes a cut on all transactions and subscriptions in the App Store).

'Software and services' has become Apple's second biggest business behind the iPhone, and last quarter, it was the company's fastest-growing segment.

It helps explain why some analysts believe software is the key to Apple's future growth.

Without getting too deep into the investment weeds, some investors are willing to ascribe higher multiples to revenue that is recurring. It has been estimated that about a third of the revenue in the App Store comes from subscriptions. In other words, software is a big part of why Apple is now eyeing off the $US1 trillion market cap mark.

Yet software and apps have also caused it headaches over the years. At times this has included its own software (for example, its Maps product, which was widely lambasted when it launched).

At other times it has been apps made by external parties.

Such as Google and Facebook, who have been at the centre of growing resentment towards the tech industry, and were the subtext to Apple's messaging this week.

Tech-lash

The tech industry has been experiencing a significant backlash from politicians and the media around the world over the past couple of years.

A variety of factors have contributed to this. Tech companies are now among the most valuable and powerful entities on the planet, with billions of users and more cash than some national governments.

In the US, there are concerns the industry has contributed to income inequality. There are also fears that some tech companies have undermined democracy.

Facebook and Google utterly failed to stem the spread of fake news during the 2016 elections in the US and during the Brexit vote in the UK. Both have also struggled to contain hate speech and other forms of disagreeable content on their platforms.

Apple has largely avoided the tech backlash. Largely, but not entirely.

The company was criticised in some quarters for a dispute in 2015 with the FBI over encryption, involving a device used by a mass shooter. It has also been criticised for its elaborate tax minimisation schemes over the years.

Earlier this year, two of Apple's own investors raised concerns about excessive iPhone use. Jana Investment Partners and the California State Teachers' Retirement System cited research claiming the average American teenager spent over 4.5 hours each day on their phone (and that excludes texting and talking); that 78 per cent of teens check their phones at least hourly, and that 50 reported feeling "addicted" to them.

"It would defy commonsense to argue that this level of usage, by children whose brains are still developing, is not having at least some impact" the two investors, which together hold $2 billion in Apple stock, said in a letter to the company.

But Apple's "digital wellness" updates this week, including ScreenTime, a dashboard feature it had quietly worked on for about a year, appear to have defused their concerns.

ScreenTime will give iPhone users the ability to get detailed data on how they use their phones (as granular as how often they pick-up and look at them) and the apps that run on them. They will be able to lock certain apps once certain usage thresholds have been met. Parents will able to use the feature for their kids.

Jana and CalSRTS seemed convinced by the initiative. "Given that we openly discussed the shortcomings of Apple's controls in our first letter, we want to be equally open today in commending you for your boldness and thoughtfulness in rethinking them" they wrote in a second missive to the company this week.

"We trust that Apple will be equally committed in your follow-through."

Other figures in the digital wellness movement, such as Tristan Harris, a former Googler who has founded the Time Well Spent imitative , and Ariana Huffington, a publishing magnate who has championed these issues, echoed similar sentiments.

With Apple's global cultural influence, this is going to dramatically accelerate a shift from a world that values constant connectivity at all costs to one that values unplugging, recharging and reducing noise and distractions #WWDC18

??? Arianna Huffington (@ariannahuff) June 4, 2018

"[T]his is going to dramatically accelerate a shift from a world that values constant connectivity at all costs to one that values unplugging, recharging and reducing noise and distractions," Huffington wrote on Twitter.

Privacy wars

Yet just after Apple announced ScreenTime at WWDC it segued into 'Memoji's' - a feature that will allow users to create emojis that look like themselves. It was strikingly incongruous from what preceded it, and shows that Apple still has work to do.

On the other big ethical issue swirling around the tech industry - privacy - the company doubled down on its long established position.

"Apple always takes a really proactive approach to privacy and to respecting people's data," Nic Wittison, an engineer from white hot Sydney design app Canva, told Fairfax at WWDC.

"Everything is always [stored] on device, they never do anything [sensitive] in the cloud. It causes other problems, but it also means everything is secure, and you don't have to worry about that kind of, hive mind knowledge going on."

Apple's Cook spent much of the week talking up his company's privacy credentials, and throwing shade at Facebook and Google. In an interview with CNN, he said regulation of tech companies would be "fair" because "this privacy thing has gotten out of control".

It came as Facebook was engulfed in more privacy scandals that could conceivably end up being even worse for it than the Cambridge Analytica episode that rocked the company to its core earlier this year.

(That scandal, which affected as many 310,000 Australians, and has resulted in an investigation by the Australian Privacy Commissioner, involved data of users unwittingly being shared with a political consultancy that worked on the Trump and Brexit campaigns in 2016).

The New York Times reported that Facebook had struck data-sharing partnerships with handset makers that could allow data of Facebook users (and their friends) to be shared without their knowledge.

Facebook has denied the essence of the report. It says the data sharing was tightly controlled and no one's information was used without their knowledge.

But it admitted the partnerships, which were struck a decade ago, existed. Participating handset makers included Apple (which itself denied seeking any intimate data about Facebook users) and China's Huawei.

The latter revelation added a geopolitical element to a story that was already veering out of control for Facebook. Tensions in the US toward China, and Chinese technology companies, are rising.

Its a similar story here in Australia. The upshot is that lawmakers in both countries (including our own Prime Minister) have spent the past couple of days talking about Facebook and privacy.

Then, to add insult to injury, on Friday morning, Facebook confirmed a software bug could mean up to 14 million of its users publicly shared information designed to be private.

Apple has clashed with other big tech companies over the years. Steve Jobs was famously full of contempt towards Google (he wanted to launch a "holy war" against the search giant, according to court documents) and vociferously attacked Abobe's Flash software.

Under Cook the company has taken a more measured approach. That changed this week. From Cook and Apple's perspective, the decision to publicly chastise Facebook couldn't have been better timed.

It remains to be seen whether Facebook, on the back foot and under fire, attempts to fight back.

In the CNN interview, Cook admitted that even he uses his iPhone too much. But his underlying argument - don't blame Apple for that - was clear. "The device is not addictive in and of itself," Cook told CNN. "It's what you do on it."

Whether the new commitment to digital wellness and the focus on privacy issues boost Apple's underlying sales of iPhones, iPads and Apple watches remains to be seen. Investors seem to think that is possible, based on the market reaction this week.

Yet taking a leadership role in digital wellness and privacy could be smart for other reasons.

The risks of regulation for most of Apple's rivals in US tech for race for the $US1 trillion crown are rising. Facebook (worth $US560 billion at press time) and Google ($US784 billion) are at risk of regulation for reasons we've discussed throughout this piece, and for their dominant, monopoly-like positions in social media and search advertising markets.

Amazon is at risk too because of its strong position on e-commerce and broader US retail, and because the Trump administration simply doesn't like the company. (Its founder and CEO Jeff Bezos, personally owns the Washington Post, which has clashed with Trump on many big stories).

Only Microsoft (worth $US775 billion) seems relatively immune from these risks, in part because it has already been through that process.

Meanwhile, nobody is seriously talking about breaking up Apple. Despite being so enormous and profitable, it doesn't have a stranglehold over the smartphone market - devices that operate on Google's Android Platformconsistently outnumber it.

And at the moment, at least, it is in the good books with the Trump administration.

All of which is to say that the race to a trillion dollar valuation is Apple's to lose.

The writer attended WWDC as a guest of Apple.

WWDC, Apple's biggest event of the year, is designed for developers, like d'Este, who helps build Procreate, a digital illustration app for the iPad. About 5000 'devs' like her made the trek to Northern California for the event this week.

Apple shares climbed to fresh highs as WWDC took place, pushing its market value to within a smidgen of the arbitrary yet still historic $US1 trillion mark ($1.3 trillion). In comparison, Facebook is worth about $US560 billion and Google $US784 billion.

In doing so, it directly addressed two of the biggest concerns swirling around the tech industry at the moment; and disarmed its biggest critics within the investment community, who have taken aim at the company on ethical grounds.

Rival consumer tech companies are no doubt less thrilled by the week's proceedings.

Arguably the most striking development of the week was Apple's barely disguised disdain for Facebook, and what it sees as a cavalier approach to privacy from the social media behemoth.

In its keynote presentation this week, Apple made a string of not so subtle references to Facebook, which has been beset by another series of privacy crises this week.

As attendees entered the hall for the keynote address, they were greeted, as is custom, with a "wall of apps" emblazoned over big giant screens. The wall pointedly excluded Facebook - the most popular free app on smartphones in the world.

Later, Apple unveiled ScreenTime, its new feature that will help users (and parents) monitor usage of the iPhones and the apps that run on them. "Some apps demand more of our attention than we even realise," Craig Federighi, Apple's top engineering executive said at the conference. "It's become such a habit we might not even realise how distracted we have become."

The example of an app that can now be tracked and monitored Apple chose to use? Instagram - owned by Facebook.

Then Apple unveiled new features in the Safari browser that will block ad-tech companies from tracking users, building detailed profiles of them, and serving them creepy ads as they surf the internet.

KEEPING YOUR BROWSING PRIVATE

Social media sharing buttons and comment fields could be used by such companies to collect data, Apple claimed. "We're shutting that down," Federighi said.

Again, the example Apple chose to use as a site that does that type of thing, which could now be stopped, was instructive: Facebook.com.

The rise of Apple under Steve Jobs in the 1980s, fall of the company in the '90s when he was ousted, and its resurgence upon his return in the 2000s, has been (very) well documented

It was Jobs' unyielding vision for the iPhone that propelled Apple into the corporate stratosphere. Less discussed is the role the software on those devices - made both by the company and by third party developers - played in that journey. The App Store, which will turn 10 next month, has become one of Apple's most effective strategic weapons, and a lucrative earner for both the company and hordes of other companies building apps for it.

"In those 10 years, the App Store has fundamentally changed the way we all live," Tim Cook, Apple's CEO and Jobs' successor, said at WWDC this week. "It's enabled countless new companies, it's created tens of millions of new jobs, and spawned entirely new industries."

Third party developers, around 5000 of whom made the trek to San Jose this week, including d'Este, have generated more than $US100 billion in earnings from the App Store over that period, he said.

That works out to be about $US14 billion annually in revenue for Apple from the App Store, according to Goldman Sachs. (Apple takes a cut on all transactions and subscriptions in the App Store.)

'Software and services' has become Apple's second-biggest business behind the iPhone, and last quarter, it was the company's fastest-growing segment. It helps explain why some analysts believe software is the key to Apple's future growth.

Without getting too deep into the investment weeds, some investors are willing to ascribe higher multiples to revenue that is recurring. It has been estimated that about a third of the revenue in the App Store comes from subscriptions. In other words, software is a big part of why Apple is now eyeing off the $US1 trillion market cap mark. Yet software and apps have also caused it headaches over the years. Earlier this year, two of Apple's own investors raised concerns about excessive iPhone use. Jana Investment Partners and the California State Teachers' Retirement System cited research claiming the average American teenager spent over 4.5 hours each day on their phone (and that excludes texting and talking); that 78 per cent of teens check their phones at least hourly, and that 50 per cent reported feeling "addicted" to them.

"It would defy common sense to argue that this level of usage, by children whose brains are still developing, is not having at least some impact", the two investors, who together hold $2 billion in Apple stock, said in a letter to the company.

But Apple's "digital wellness" updates this week, including ScreenTime, a dashboard feature it had quietly worked on for about a year, appear to have defused their concerns.

ScreenTime will give iPhone users the ability to get detailed data on how they use their phones (as granular as how often they pick up and look at them) and the apps that run on them. "Given that we openly discussed the shortcomings of Apple's controls in our first letter, we want to be equally open today in commending you for your boldness and thoughtfulness in rethinking them" they wrote in a second letter to the company this week. "We trust that Apple will be equally committed in your follow-through."

Other figures in the digital wellness movement, such as Tristan Harris, a former Googler who has founded the Time Well Spent imitative , and Ariana Huffington, a publishing magnate who has championed these issues, echoed similar sentiments.

Yet just after Apple announced ScreenTime at WWDC it segued into 'Memoji's' - a feature that will allow users to create emojis that look like themselves. It was strikingly incongruous from what preceded it, and shows that Apple still has work to do. "Everything is always [stored] on device, they never do anything [sensitive] in the cloud. It causes other problems, but it also means everything is secure, and you don't have to worry about that kind of, hive-mind knowledge going on.'

(That scandal, which affected as many as 310,000 Australians, and has resulted in an investigation by the Australian Privacy Commissioner, involved data of users unwittingly being shared with a political consultancy that worked on the Trump and Brexit campaigns in 2016.)

The New York Times reported that Facebook had struck data-sharing partnerships with handset makers that could allow data of Facebook users (and their friends) to be shared without their knowledge. Facebook has denied the essence of the report. It says the data sharing was tightly controlled and no one's information was used without their knowledge.

But it admitted the partnerships existed. Participating handset makers included Apple (which itself denied seeking any intimate data about Facebook users) and China's Huawei.

Amazon is at risk too because of its strong position on e-commerce and broader US retail, and because the Trump administration simply doesn't like the company. (Its founder and CEO Jeff Bezos, personally owns The Washington Post, which has clashed with Trump on many big stories).

Only Microsoft (worth $US775 billion) seems relatively immune from regulatory risks, in part because it has already been through that process.

Meanwhile, nobody is seriously talking about breaking up Apple. Despite being so enormous and profitable, it doesn't exactly dominate he smartphone market - devices that operate on Google's Android platform consistently outperform it. And at the moment, at least, it is in the good books with the Trump administration.

All of which is to say that the race to a trillion-dollar valuation is Apple's to lose.

Facebook (worth $US560 billion at press time) and Google ($US784 billion) are at risk of regulation for reasons we've discussed throughout this piece, and for their dominant, monopoly-like positions in social media and search advertising markets.

Amazon is at risk too because of its strong position on e-commerce and broader US retail, and because the Trump administration simply doesn't like the company. (Its founder and CEO Jeff Bezos, personally owns The Washington Post, which has clashed with Trump on many big stories).

Only Microsoft (worth $US775 billion) seems relatively immune from regulatory risks, in part because it has already been through that process.

Meanwhile, nobody is seriously talking about breaking up Apple. Despite being so enormous and profitable, it doesn't exactly dominate he smartphone market - devices that operate on Google's Android platform consistently outperform it. And at the moment, at least, it is in the good books with the Trump administration.

All of which is to say that the race to a trillion-dollar valuation is Apple's to lose.

urn:contentItem:58H4-69T1-DY9P-N36B-00000-00PLAYING THE TAX GAME;Some of our best-known - and best-loved - firms enjoy a free ride. It's time to make them pay their dues, write John Arlidge and Jon Ungoed-Thomas2013-05-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 20PLAYING THE TAX GAMESome of our best-known - and best-loved - firms enjoy a free ride. It's time to make them pay their dues, write John Arlidge and Jon Ungoed-ThomasJohn Arlidge; Jon Ungoed-Thomas

Asif al-Najjar runs the Surf 'n' Click internet coffee bar in west London. His chalkboard menu tempts customers with danish pastries, french fancies and Italian coffee.

He does not offer the Dutch sandwich or the double Irish - but is beginning to think he should. "I pay 23% business tax. Starbucks next door pays almost nothing. It's not fair," he says.

The Dutch sandwich and the double Irish describe complex methods multinational firms use to avoid tax. Most of the profits Starbucks, Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple - and many other companies - make in Britain are routed to Holland, Luxembourg and Ireland to take advantage of those countries' lower tax rates.

As a result, they can pay as little as 1% on the billions of pounds of revenues they generate in Britain.

Last week, however, the big firms' tax avoidance came back to bite them, after one of Google's former employees disclosed how UK sales were being booked in Ireland to avoid tax.

Barney Jones, 34, a former executive, told The Sunday Times that online advertising sales had in fact been made in this country - and he believed tax should have been paid. The real victims, he said, were ordinary taxpayers.

The growing row prompted pledges from the party leaders to crack down on tax avoidance. David Cameron announced that he would make it a priority as he assumes the chairmanship of the group of eight leading economies.

Ed Miliband accused Google, whose corporate motto is "Don't be evil", of acting unethically - in a speech at its own "big tent" event in Hertfordshire.

While Google faced British brickbats, Apple was in the stocks in America. A US Senate committee last week accused the company of seeking the holy grail of tax avoidance, creating "offshore entities holding tens of billions of dollars, while claiming to be tax resident nowhere".

Late last week the tech giants fought back, insisting that they comply with all tax laws and pay "extraordinary" amounts of tax. They are now joining politicians in calling for an overhaul of the global tax system.

Eric Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google, said: "I can't defend the international tax regime. I did not design such an irrational structure."

HOW did we get into this mess? And more importantly, how can we encourage, cajole or force the multinationals to pay their fair dues? There is nothing new about tax havens: companies, institutions and private individuals have been using them for more than 100 years.

Recently, however, many firms have begun to exploit these havens more aggressively.

The sums of tax that companies and wealthy individuals avoid has been growing by 15% a year for the past decade. Today, up to $32 trillion is held offshore. Tax avoidance costs the UK tens of billions of pounds a year.

Thanks to the increasing globalisation of trade, multinational corporations find it ever easier to shuttle profits - and sometimes even their headquarters - around the globe in search of the jurisdiction willing to cut them the best tax deal.

Much of this is done using "transfer pricing", in which one subsidiary of a multinational sells products and services to another subsidiary often at an artificial price in order to make profits seem higher in a low-tax country - and lower in a high-tax one.

This process is helped by the changing nature of what many firms sell: a large slice of the revenues of Google, Apple and Amazon come from intangible products such as electronic books, MP3 files and computer games.

It is easy to set up a company in a low-tax country and process sales of "virtual" items or collect fees or royalties for the use of an idea.

Google had turnover of £2.7bn in the UK in 2011. It catapults those revenues around the world, from Holland to Ireland to Bermuda, to minimise tax liabilities. It paid just £6m tax in 2011. Apple and Amazon operate similarly circuitous money flows. Together, the two companies had revenues of about £10bn in the UK in 2011 but paid less than £17m in tax.

Last November Matt Brittin, a Google vice-president, justified his company's tax arrangements to a parliamentary committee on the grounds that it did not sell advertising in this country. Some former Google sales executives were mystified by the claim.

Brittin subsequently clarified his remarks to say sales were not concluded in this country, but the damage was done.

A Reuters investigation picked apart the claim that Google sales teams were not active in this country and last weekend Jones came forward to The Sunday Times.

He wielded a dossier of 100,000 emails and documents which he claimed proved Google advertising sales were conducted and concluded in the UK during his four years at the company. On Monday, he met officials from HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) and handed over the dossier.

"Sales were being made in the UK and I suspect there might be a rather large tax bill for Google at the end of this," Jones said last week. "I certainly hope the British taxpayers get some money back. "It seems to me some of the largest companies have been running rings around HMRC. Someone needs to take proper charge of this issue."

The laceration of Apple's tax affairs by a US Senate committee helped further push the issue on to the global agenda.

The big tech firms seem to agree that tax codes are out of date and reform is needed. Tim Cook, Apple's chief executive, argued last week for a "dramatic simplification" of tax laws. Schmidt has also made clear he supports an overhaul of the global system.

British analysts agree. Richard Brooks, a former HMRC corporate tax inspector who quit eight years ago in disgust at what he saw as the authority's failure to tackle corporate tax avoidance, says: "The basics of today's global tax rules were drawn up in the 1920s under the League of Nations. Since then, the authorities have not kept up with with telegraph and the telephone, let alone the internet." Regulation is "as bad as regulation of the banks before the economic crisis", he adds.

Even the man in charge of global tax policy at the OECD, the body that crafts international rules on taxation, Pascal Saint-Amans, says the system is rotten. "Aggressive tax planning needs to be stopped with firmer rules," he says. But how? SOME hope big firms will see the damage the tax row is doing to their brand value and volunteer to pay more. Earlier this year, Starbucks agreed to add an extra £10m shot of corporation tax to its 2013-14 accounts but no other firm has indicated it will follow suit.

There is also the possibility of consumer boycotts: a recent brand preference survey showed a drop in Starbucks' standing among coffee drinkers, which may explain a surge in sales for its British rival Costa.

Can politicians help? Cameron has been talking tough on tax reform, but critics say he has not been acting tough. Last week, he welcomed Schmidt, a member of the government's Business Advisory Group, to 10 Downing Street, but did not tackle the Google boss directly on his firm's tax avoidance.

George Osborne, the chancellor, has gone one better. He welcomed another taxavoiding tech titan, the Facebook chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg, to No 11 last month, not to discuss tax but to host a champagne party to launch Lean In, her new book.

Brooks believes the government's own proposed reform of the controlled foreign company rules might even make it easier for big firms to avoid tax in future.

One reason for the politicians' failure to match their words with action appears to be a belief that low taxes encourage high investment.

"I believe in low taxes for business, because we've got to encourage investment, and we''ve got to encourage jobs," Cameron said last week.

Also, despite widespread aggressive avoidance - and the recession - the corporation tax take in the UK is holding up (see table).

If, against the odds, politicians did get their act together, could they make real changes? Prem Sikka, a leading UK tax expert, argues global leaders could agree to treat multinational companies as a single global entity, instead of lots of different subsidiaries, and divide up their profits fairly country by country, according to where their real economic activity takes place. The firms would then pay whatever tax each country decided to levy.

This idea, called unitary taxation, is compellingly simple and the EU has agreed to force big firms to reveal corporate profits and taxes on a countryby-country basis.

But it would require governments to agree a global formula for dividing taxable profits "fairly".

Past experience suggests that, with so much at stake, this could be tricky.

Germany and France tried to pressure Ireland to give up its low 12.5% corporation tax by threatening to veto the (EURO)85bn EU bailout package for Dublin three years ago. But not even the threat of losing (EURO)85bn could persuade the Irish to budge. In the end, Paris and Berlin backed down.

Could one country act on its own? Miliband has pledged to change laws unilaterally to stop transfer pricing and clamp down on offshore tax havens. Nick Shaxson, author of Treasure Islands and a leading expert on offshore finance, says: "Labour could quite easily close some of the tax loopholes firms now exploit."

But forcing a multinational such as Google to declare all the sales it makes in Britain in Britain, rather than in Ireland, would involve renegotiating the UK's tax treaty with Dublin. And even if that happened, Google could simply route its British profits through another tax haven, say, Luxembourg.

Brooks, author of The Great Tax Robbery, admits: "There are things that, in theory, you could do to stop tax avoidance but they require global agreements which are, in practice, very difficult to get."

Nobody underestimates the scale of the challenge in reaching such agreements, but there is undoubtedly growing support among corporations, government - and the public - for reform.

A successful resolution would ensure a fairer and more transparent system. For al-Najjar at the Surf 'n' Click coffee bar, the demise of the Dutch sandwich and an iniquitous global tax regime cannot come soon enough.

A tip for the untaxables: give your cash away, Adam Boulton, page 23.

urn:contentItem:58H4-69T1-DY9P-N3N0-00000-00PLAYING THE TAX GAME;Some of our best-known - and best-loved - firms enjoy a free ride. It's time to make them pay their dues, write John Arlidge and Jon Ungoed-Thomas2013-05-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 22PLAYING THE TAX GAMESome of our best-known - and best-loved - firms enjoy a free ride. It's time to make them pay their dues, write John Arlidge and Jon Ungoed-ThomasJohn Arlidge

Asif al-Najjar runs the Surf 'n' Click internet coffee bar in west London. His chalkboard menu tempts customers with danish pastries, french fancies and Italian coffee.

He does not offer the Dutch sandwich or the double Irish - but is beginning to think he should. "I pay 23% business tax. Starbucks next door pays almost nothing. It's not fair," he says.

The Dutch sandwich and the double Irish describe complex methods multinational firms use to avoid tax. Most of the profits Starbucks, Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple - and many other companies - make in Britain are routed to Holland, Luxembourg and Ireland to take advantage of those countries' lower tax rates.

As a result, they can pay as little as 1% on the billions of pounds of revenues they generate in Britain.

Last week, however, the big firms' tax avoidance came back to bite them, after one of Google's former employees disclosed how UK sales were being booked in Ireland to avoid tax.

Barney Jones, 34, a former executive, told The Sunday Times that online advertising sales had in fact been made in this country - and he believed tax should have been paid. The real victims, he said, were ordinary taxpayers.

The growing row prompted pledges from the party leaders to crack down on tax avoidance. David Cameron announced that he would make it a priority as he assumes the chairmanship of the group of eight leading economies.

Ed Miliband accused Google, whose corporate motto is "Don't be evil", of acting unethically - in a speech at its own "big tent" event in Hertfordshire.

While Google faced British brickbats, Apple was in the stocks in America. A US Senate committee last week accused the company of seeking the holy grail of tax avoidance, creating "offshore entities holding tens of billions of dollars, while claiming to be tax resident nowhere".

Late last week the tech giants fought back, insisting that they comply with all tax laws and pay "extraordinary" amounts of tax. They are now joining politicians in calling for an overhaul of the global tax system.

Eric Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google, said: "I can't defend the international tax regime. I did not design such an irrational structure."

HOW did we get into this mess? And more importantly, how can we encourage, cajole or force the multinationals to pay their fair dues? There is nothing new about tax havens: companies, institutions and private individuals have been using them for more than 100 years.

Recently, however, many firms have begun to exploit these havens more aggressively.

The sums of tax that companies and wealthy individuals avoid has been growing by 15% a year for the past decade. Today, up to $32 trillion is held offshore. Tax avoidance costs the UK tens of billions of pounds a year.

Thanks to the increasing globalisation of trade, multinational corporations find it ever easier to shuttle profits - and sometimes even their headquarters - around the globe in search of the jurisdiction willing to cut them the best tax deal.

Much of this is done using "transfer pricing", in which one subsidiary of a multinational sells products and services to another subsidiary often at an artificial price in order to make profits seem higher in a low-tax country - and lower in a high-tax one.

This process is helped by the changing nature of what many firms sell: a large slice of the revenues of Google, Apple and Amazon come from intangible products such as electronic books, MP3 files and computer games.

It is easy to set up a company in a low-tax country and process sales of "virtual" items or collect fees or royalties for the use of an idea.

Google had turnover of £2.7bn in the UK in 2011. It catapults those revenues around the world, from Holland to Ireland to Bermuda, to minimise tax liabilities. It paid just £6m tax in 2011. Apple and Amazon operate similarly circuitous money flows. Together, the two companies had revenues of about £10bn in the UK in 2011 but paid less than £17m in tax.

Last November Matt Brittin, a Google vice-president, justified his company's tax arrangements to a parliamentary committee on the grounds that it did not sell advertising in this country. Some former Google sales executives were mystified by the claim.

Brittin subsequently clarified his remarks to say sales were not concluded in this country, but the damage was done.

A Reuters investigation picked apart the claim that Google sales teams were not active in this country and last weekend Jones came forward to The Sunday Times.

He wielded a dossier of 100,000 emails and documents which he claimed proved Google advertising sales were conducted and concluded in the UK during his four years at the company. On Monday, he met officials from HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) and handed over the dossier.

"Sales were being made in the UK and I suspect there might be a rather large tax bill for Google at the end of this," Jones said last week. "I certainly hope the British taxpayers get some money back. "It seems to me some of the largest companies have been running rings around HMRC. Someone needs to take proper charge of this issue."

The laceration of Apple's tax affairs by a US Senate committee helped further push the issue on to the global agenda.

The big tech firms seem to agree that tax codes are out of date and reform is needed. Tim Cook, Apple's chief executive, argued last week for a "dramatic simplification" of tax laws. Schmidt has also made clear he supports an overhaul of the global system.

British analysts agree. Richard Brooks, a former HMRC corporate tax inspector who quit eight years ago in disgust at what he saw as the authority's failure to tackle corporate tax avoidance, says: "The basics of today's global tax rules were drawn up in the 1920s under the League of Nations. Since then, the authorities have not kept up with with telegraph and the telephone, let alone the internet." Regulation is "as bad as regulation of the banks before the economic crisis", he adds.

Even the man in charge of global tax policy at the OECD, the body that crafts international rules on taxation, Pascal Saint-Amans, says the system is rotten. "Aggressive tax planning needs to be stopped with firmer rules," he says. But how? SOME hope big firms will see the damage the tax row is doing to their brand value and volunteer to pay more. Earlier this year, Starbucks agreed to add an extra £10m shot of corporation tax to its 2013-14 accounts but no other firm has indicated it will follow suit.

There is also the possibility of consumer boycotts: a recent brand preference survey showed a drop in Starbucks' standing among coffee drinkers, which may explain a surge in sales for its British rival Costa.

Can politicians help? Cameron has been talking tough on tax reform, but critics say he has not been acting tough. Last week, he welcomed Schmidt, a member of the government's Business Advisory Group, to 10 Downing Street, but did not tackle the Google boss directly on his firm's tax avoidance.

George Osborne, the chancellor, has gone one better. He welcomed another taxavoiding tech titan, the Facebook chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg, to No 11 last month, not to discuss tax but to host a champagne party to launch Lean In, her new book.

Brooks believes the government's own proposed reform of the controlled foreign company rules might even make it easier for big firms to avoid tax in future.

One reason for the politicians' failure to match their words with action appears to be a belief that low taxes encourage high investment.

"I believe in low taxes for business, because we've got to encourage investment, and we''ve got to encourage jobs," Cameron said last week.

Also, despite widespread aggressive avoidance - and the recession - the corporation tax take in the UK is holding up (see table).

If, against the odds, politicians did get their act together, could they make real changes? Prem Sikka, a leading UK tax expert, argues global leaders could agree to treat multinational companies as a single global entity, instead of lots of different subsidiaries, and divide up their profits fairly country by country, according to where their real economic activity takes place. The firms would then pay whatever tax each country decided to levy.

This idea, called unitary taxation, is compellingly simple and the EU has agreed to force big firms to reveal corporate profits and taxes on a countryby-country basis.

But it would require governments to agree a global formula for dividing taxable profits "fairly".

Past experience suggests that, with so much at stake, this could be tricky.

Germany and France tried to pressure Ireland to give up its low 12.5% corporation tax by threatening to veto the (EURO)85bn EU bailout package for Dublin three years ago. But not even the threat of losing (EURO)85bn could persuade the Irish to budge. In the end, Paris and Berlin backed down.

Could one country act on its own? Miliband has pledged to change laws unilaterally to stop transfer pricing and clamp down on offshore tax havens. Nick Shaxson, author of Treasure Islands and a leading expert on offshore finance, says: "Labour could quite easily close some of the tax loopholes firms now exploit."

But forcing a multinational such as Google to declare all the sales it makes in Britain in Britain, rather than in Ireland, would involve renegotiating the UK's tax treaty with Dublin. And even if that happened, Google could simply route its British profits through another tax haven, say, Luxembourg.

Brooks, author of The Great Tax Robbery, admits: "There are things that, in theory, you could do to stop tax avoidance but they require global agreements which are, in practice, very difficult to get."

Nobody underestimates the scale of the challenge in reaching such agreements, but there is undoubtedly growing support among corporations, government - and the public - for reform.

A successful resolution would ensure a fairer and more transparent system. For al-Najjar at the Surf 'n' Click coffee bar, the demise of the Dutch sandwich and an iniquitous global tax regime cannot come soon enough.
