(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Good Wednesday morning everybody. Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Wednesday, September 14. Here are your top stories, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Hillary Clinton off the campaign trail for a third straight day but the questions over her private e-mail server are looming large during a congressional hearing. And Donald Trump is on the attack on it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: This attitude of arrogance that explains why Hillary Clinton made 13 phones disappear including with a hammer, so the FBI couldn't see them. And why she bleached her e-mails after a congressional subpoena -- that's after the subpoena came.

Now the people who destroyed the e-mails are all pleading the Fifth Amendment in front of Congress. Anyone watching today's hearing in Congress knows that Hillary Clinton's actions are far more corrupt.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The latest on the race to the White House coming up.

Plus protecting your finances. The Wells Fargo scandal raising questions for bank customers across the country. What you need to know to keep your money safe -- coming up.

A rough start for Apple's latest software upgrade -- the update causing major problems for users sparking social media outrage. We'll bring it to you.

And taking the smart home to a new level. Amazon teams up with General Electric so you can remotely preheat your oven and start your laundry.

Concealed carry hits the runway. We have a look at one company that's making it easier for women to carry their weapons. Yes.

In markets, futures edging higher this morning -- another big move yesterday and we are extending that move. Take a look. The markets are expected to open fractionally better on the session today.

In Europe the tone was set higher, led by a rebound in the price of oil. FT 100 up two-thirds of a percent now.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board. And the Kospi in Korea closed for a holiday.

We've got all of those stories coming up this hour.

And joining me to talk about it Maverick PAC national co-chair Morgan Ortagus; Kingsview Asset Management Scott Martin; and former CIA operative and Diligence president, Mike Baker.

Wow, what a story on Google just there.

MIKE BAKER, FORMER CIA OPERATIVE: It's incredible. When you do think about what could be happening. And this is just the tip of the iceberg. This is just saying that Google is impacting your searches on Hillary Clinton.

Then you think, well, are they also impacting your searches on issues that, you know, favor Hillary Clinton's point of view. I mean this thing just goes on and on.

BARTIROMO: Like the refugee crisis.

BAKER: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Like health care.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, MAVERICK PAC: It's no surprise, Maria, that there's big mistrust of everything in big government and big institutions and big tech. That's why were seeing this play out in this election cycle. People have a fundamental lack of trust in the institutions and organizations and corporations that seem to control our lives.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're going to talk all about that.

SCOTT MARTIN, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: They control your lives and Google is in home, it's on your smart phone, it's on your tablet.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And the problem is you don't know it. You don't realize but you could be actually being taken advantage of.

We've got a can't-miss lineup this hour. Stay with us. We are about to speak with former U.S. Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, we will ask him his opinion on this; former Hillary Clinton presidential campaign senior adviser Mark Penn is with us; and former Yum Brands chairman and CEO David Novak stops by as well.

Meanwhile outrage on Capitol Hill this morning. Three former Clinton workers refusing to testify before a congressional oversight committee yesterday regarding the Democratic nominee's use of a private server. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: On the advice of counsel I respectfully decline to answer and observe my Fifth Amendment privilege.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I respectfully decline to answer and observe my Fifth Amendment constitutional privilege.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I have no opening statement.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Former Bill Clinton aide, Justin Cooper also took the stand but he actually answered questions. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JASON CHAFFETZ (R), UTAH: Did you have a security clearance at that time?

JUSTIN COOPER, FORMER BILL CLINTON AIDE: No I did not have a security clearance.

CHAFFETZ: After you left the White House early in -- when did you leave the White House?

COOPER: 2001.

CHAFFETZ: 2001. Did you ever have a security clearance at any level after that?

COOPER: No, I did not have a security clearance.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Was your purpose in destroying the old Blackberry device ever to hide Secretary Clinton's e-mails from being saved or disclosed from federal records laws.

COOPER: Congresswoman, no. It's not in any way to destroy or hide any information at all. I was going out of my way to preserve all of the information that was on those devices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Right. That's why he used a hammer to destroy the device to save it.

Joining me right now is a member of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, Florida Congressman John Mica. Congressman -- good to have you on the program. Thanks very much for joining us.

REP. JOHN MICA (R), FLORIDA: Good to be with you. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Your takeaway from the happenings yesterday.

MICA: Well, I think they're trying to run the clock out. We saw one witness not show up, thumb his nose at Congress, two that took the Fifth Amendment and the other we learned some information from -- this has been a cat and mouse game from the beginning.

We started with Benghazi trying to find out what took place, who did what and we just keep getting the stall and not the information that Congress is entitled to.

BARTIROMO: So I mean does this just mean you are powerless in this regard? I mean what are you going to do? One guy, Pagliano, decides it's just not imp. I'm not showing up. He blows it off. You have the other two not revealing anything. And then Justin Cooper, no pushback on the fact that he says oh no, I was trying to preserve information. But we know he's the guy with the hammer. What happens now -- Congressman?

MICA: Again, we have to follow the law and the rules of procedure. Pagliano did not show up. He can be held as I questioned the chairman in attempt of Congress. A referral would then go to the Department of Justice and there could be proceedings, criminal proceeding possibly against him.

Right now were looking at the options. I don't know if the chairman will give him another opportunity to come forward. I don't know whether there are other remedies from a legal standpoint we have.

But again, you see a stalling game. This guy played the same thing with the FBI. We think he was granted immunity, we don't know to what extent. But he should have at least showed up if he wanted to exercise his right like the other two did, he could take the Fifth Amendment before us.

But again this is just a continuum of stalling; failing to give Congress the information we are entitled to. We are entitled to conduct a thorough investigation. Our committee has charge over all matters for investigations under the House of Representatives. And they are thwarting that process.

BARTIROMO: Right. Morgan.

ORTAGUS: Good morning -- Congressman. Hillary Clinton had gotten a pass by the FBI. We know this already. But can you tell me what is going on with her top aides? Are you still investigating them in Congress? We saw last week on the show that immunity was granted to yet another person on the server even though we thought the investigation was closed.

What is going on with the people who are actually in control of this information of this e-mail? We haven't really heard and I think the American people would like to know what is happening to those people in power.

MICA: Well, we heard from one witness a little bit of information. We are trying to gather all the facts because you can't proceed without the facts. Some information we did learn and we seized from some of the FBI 302s.

It appears that people like Cheryl Mills, one of the aides to the secretary possibly ordered some of the destruction of the (inaudible) that should have been preserved. We have a requirement to preserve records even though she had them on a private server. She had classified information and other information that wasn't properly turned over and may have been destroyed.

So we're trying to find out what took place. And every time we turn to another witness, we find out there is more. When they talk to the FBI they suddenly dump new found e-mails. It is a stall to try to run out the clock. And we are, I think entitled to complete the investigation in a proper and thorough manner.

BARTIROMO: Of course. Here's Mike Baker.

BAKER: Yes. Congressman -- good morning. There used to be a sense that there were consequences for action. And I think there is a frustration out there in the American public that perhaps things just go to the Hill and die nowadays whether it's the Benghazi investigation or any other investigation regardless of where on the political spectrum it stands.

BARTIROMO: IRS.

BAKER: Yes -- IRS. What is your timeframe for this particular situation where Brian Pagliano ignores a subpoena, doesn't show up. You know, I realize you have to follow procedures but you're also Congress. And do you have the ability to move at your own pace here and what will your timeframe be to deal with that?

MICA: Well, unlike some here, we do comply with the constitution with the constraints imposed on us. Even Congress has constraints. So we can't go and prosecute. Now we have to see again what was done in contravention of the law and the rules, take the steps that are allowed under the law. Unfortunately we have a Department of Justice whether it's been Loretta Lynch or Holder that are non-responsive and turned a blind eye.

We have a very difficult situation, a very difficult job. But, you know, this is kind of like that old law enforcement serial on TV. All we want are the facts ma'am. And our job is to get the facts for the public and then take action. But we have to do that.

If they want to be lawless our side of the aisle is not going to be. We want to comply with the law and the proper procedures.

BARTIROMO: But when you say they're trying to, you know, wipe the clock out, you know, let the clock run out does that mean that they're going to just let the clock run out until the end of the couple of months and let the election happen and then they're hoping Hillary Clinton wins and then it just dies and goes away because she's president. Is that what you're saying?

MICA: Well, again, they already have control of the Department of Justice. It appears the FBI may have been compromised from there. And it's much disappointing with the Director Comey who has had a fairly good reputation not to give us the information. You may recall during the hearings I said the secretary and her interview recorded. No. Do you have any information from that? Yes we have the 302s. We still don't have the 302s from that and some have been kept from us.

They are playing a cat and mouse game whether it's the Department of Justice, now the FBI. It's a very sad time for our judicial system and the process that should move forward in an orderly manner under the constitution laws of the United States.

BARTIROMO: Yes. What a disgrace for the American people if all of these agencies have become compromised and politicized at this point.

Congressman -- thanks very much for your insights. We appreciate this.

MICA: Good to be with you. We will continue this.

BARTIROMO: And so will we. John Mica -- joining us.

Go ahead Mike Baker.

BAKER: Yes. I think that was very interesting what he just said. It was almost a throwaway comment where he said that the FBI may have been compromised as well. What I would say is I don't know Director Comey's motivation for his decision that he made recently. I will say this. I've had the good fortune of working with the FBI over the years including recently and I know some of those folks. The agents there at the FBI, they are not compromised. This is not an issue regarding the agents or the FBI.

This is -- and again, not knowing what Director Comey's concerns are -- DOJ, is it political? Of course. But the FBI -- those folks do their job and investigate.

BARTIROMO: I know some FBI agents, too and I agree with you. They are --

MARTIN: Look at all the evidence we dug out.

BAKER: Right.

BARTIROMO: What happened to Jim Comey?

BAKER: You know what, it's a question I don't know where we're going to get an answer to. And it surprised a lot of people. You remember the talk in Washington was all before his decision. He's a great. He's completely nonpartisan. He is the most nonpartisan person there.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But the interview was not recorded. The interview wasn't on the record. Basically her lawyers told the FBI look, if you record this she's not showing up.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Ok, we won't record.

ORTAGUS: And he let Loretta Lynch off the hook two days after she met on a private plane with Bill Clinton for 30 minutes.

BAKER: Right.

BARTIROMO: Explain that to us.

ORTAGUS: It's as political as it gets.

BARTIROMO: We're going to talk about this tomorrow as well when we have a special guest. Governor Mike Pence will join us tomorrow, 8:30 a.m. Eastern right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Don't miss our special interview tomorrow coming up with Governor Mike Pence.

Still to come: as Hillary rests, President Obama is on the attack. The details as he hits the campaign trail. We'll tell you the reception that the President got as he stumps for Hillary.

Plus move over buffalo. We are testing Burger King's new Cheetos chicken. How's that for breakfast?

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Well, the hacker known as Guccifer 2.0 releasing more DNC documents.

Cheryl Casone with that and the headlines now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Maria.

Well, Guccifer 2.0 disclosed the documents at a cyber security conference in London yesterday. They include the Democratic National Committee's finances and network infrastructure. Among them Democratic vice presidential candidate Tim Kaine cell phone number and the contact information for several top White House officials. U.S. intelligence officials suspect Russian involvement.

Well, if you upgraded your Apple device to the latest IOS software yesterday and you didn't have a problem. You were one of the lucky ones. Some people were hit by a major bug that left their devices temporarily useless.

There are reports that some of the upgrades resulted in a so-called bricked iPhone or iPad. Basically when that happens your device has a black screen and access is totally blocked. Those unlucky people had to plug the devices into their computers, connect to iTunes and restore their devices completely. This is why you should always backup your phone, folks. Apple acknowledging the problem; they later did say that they had resolved it.

And finally, we first told you about this new item from Burger King yesterday, Cheetos Chicken fries. But they're out today. You have to eat lunch at some point right. So before we dive into them on set because, of course, I brought them, we should tell you that the fries are made with all white meat chicken. They are covered in a flavored breading that includes crushed up Cheetos. Nine-piece order, $2.89 Maria and for all of you watching your waistlines one order is 280 calories.

And I brought them to try because I think we should try things like this.

BARTIROMO: I'm supposed to believe that this is 280 calories.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: 280 calories -- would I lie to you Maria Bartiromo.

BARTIROMO: If only our viewers can smell what I smell on this set right now -- wow.

MARTIN: What's the calorie count? Is the calorie count per the order?

BARTIROMO: This is 280 calories.

CASONE: Yes, ma'am.

ORTAGUS: You can taste the Cheetos.

CASONE: You can taste the Cheetos?

ORTAGUS: I'm from Florida, ma'am. We love our junk food. The taste is great.

BARTIROMO: Can you taste any chicken?

MARTIN: This is the breakfast of champions, baby.

BARTIROMO: Just tasty.

MARTIN: If you have this with the Red Bull and Vodka in the morning your day is set.

(CROSSTALK)

BAKER: I'll tell you what, that's the breakfast of champions right there.

BARTIROMO: While you're enjoying your breakfast, ladies and gentlemen, let me tell you we do have breaking news.

Bayer is acquiring Monsanto -- the deal is done, Scott Martin as we expected.

MARTIN: Have fun with the regulators on that one. I mean they blocked so many of this, this year. It's good to see this being done. What's funny about this deal too, Maria, agriculture.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MARTIN: Agriculture prices have been falling through the floor. So it's interesting to see these two companies get together.

BARTIROMO: It's $128, $128 a share.

BAKER: You know what's interesting also is what Charlie Gasparino reported earlier which is if the EU or DOJ or both decide to nix this deal, Monsanto walks away with a $2 billion check. And a lifetime supply of chicken fries. It's a good deal for that.

BARTIROMO: Look at this, the deal is at $128. The stock is still at $106. So go figure. Why is that $128?

MARTIN: I think the market does not trust the regulators.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: So they don't think -- somebody doesn't trust --

(CROSSTALK)

MARTIN: This is the biggest deal of 2016, boys and girls and so, of course, the regulators are going to get involved in this. They're not going to let this just walk through.

ORTAGUS: Well, you've got to get through the Europeans and the Americans. It's not just the American regulators. It's the EU which is just so efficient.

CASONE: Yes.

BAKER: Is everybody else eating these chicken fries?

(CROSSTALK)

MARTIN: Mike's almost out of chicken fries. He knows that --

BAKER: I'm going to have yours and yours.

MARTIN: -- chicken fries so fast.

CASONE: There's honey --

BARTIROMO: 280 calories -- Scott.

ORTAGUS: I like this one. This one is zesty and has horse radish. So it's good.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: I think the 280 does not include the sauce.

BARTIROMO: Now we hear new information -- Cheryl.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: Thank you-- Burger King.

BAKER: And your fingers are not covered in Cheeto dust.

BARTIROMO: Ok. I hope you're having breakfast at home with us.

Wells Fargo's phony account scandal putting fraud in the spotlight -- what you need to protect your money.

Plus making a smart home a reality -- the big name Amazon is teaming up with to bring the future to life.

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Shares of Wells Fargo plummeting over the outrage surrounding the phony bank accounts costing the company its standing as the largest U.S. bank by market capitalization. JP Morgan back up to number one.

Many hold the bank's sales targets responsible for employee creating unauthorized accounts. But Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf is shifting the blame to employees. He said quote, "There was no incentive to do bad things."

Joining me right now is former FBI white collar crime expert Ken Springer and IDT 911 founder Adam Levin. Good to see you gentlemen. Thank you so much for joining us.

Ken, let me kick it off with you. What do you think was behind this because now people are saying if this was so prevalent as Wells Fargo -- 5,300 employees creating this phony accounts, are we going to see this at other banks?

KEN SPRINGER, FORMER FBI WHITE COLLAR CRIME EXPERT: Well, I don't know if it's a fraud or a conspiracy because you can't have 5,300 people involved in that. I think more than anything it's probably aggressive sales practices.

And I think if the FBI gets involved they can probably talk to some of these people and they're going to find out what really happened. Was it limited to one region? How far up the ladder does it go?

And I think the bigger issue is going to be if they did this would they have opened other accounts for bad actors -- whether it's drug dealers, money launderers and others.

BARTIROMO: And we don't know that. I mean we don't know who the accounts were for -- right.

SPRINGER: That hasn't come out.

BART: Ok. So the sales targets, Ken, were set by higher level executives. One executive actually is leaving the bank with $126 million payday. Since then Wells Fargo has to pay hundred $185 million in fines for defrauding customers. This reported payday that Carrie Tolstedt is walking out with, does this add to the wrongdoing in your view? How does that play into this? This doesn't look good.

SPRINGER: We don't know. It doesn't look good. And it goes back to I think when Mary Jo White took over the SEC. She talked about not letting financial institutions say without admitting or denying guilt, paying the fine and moving on. I think they're going to see if there's someone who should be held accountable for this violation.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And Adam, you've got a book "Swiped: How to protect yourself in a world full of scammer, phishers and identity thieves". Will you explain to us how we can protect our money at banks with what we see happening.

ADAM LEVIN, IDT 911 FOUNDER: Well, you know, again, here is a situation where the bank ran off with the stork, consumers ended up holding the bag that this system encouraged this kind of action. And the things I talk about in the book is you have to realize this is a classic definition of identity theft that occurred. People were using the personally identifiable, sensitive information of other people for their gain.

So what consumers need to do is they need to do a number of things. First, you need to monitor. You should be checking your accounts on a daily basis. You should be signing up for what is called transactional monitoring alerts which means that any time there's any activity in your accounts, you're notified of it and you should be specifically looking for small charges or what they like to call ghost charges because usually they are designed in order to evade bank systems and to evade consumer scrutiny.

BARTIROMO: Right.

LEVIN: You should also consider freezing your credit so that nobody including you can get access to your credit for the purpose of opening up a credit card account.

BARTIROMO: That's death by a thousand cuts -- Mike.

BAKER: What you think is the proper response at this stage? What should they do -- senior management within Well Fargo?

LEVIN: I think that people have to walk the plank. And I'm not just talking about lower level people. I think higher-level people -- the confidence of consumers has been shaken in this financial institution. And as a result it will be shaken in other financial institutions and don't forget, the scandal that happened a few years ago where a number of financial institutions were reordering the chronology of debit accounts -- debit charges in order to put the consumer over on the first charge to charge multiple over limit fees which is one of the things that led to the Credit Card Reform Act.

MARTIN: And that's the scary thing. I mean this was going on for years and years and years under Ms. Tolstedt's watch or on her watch and she was able to stay in the position. People were getting fired in her department yet the banking executive did nothing about it.

BARTIROMO: It doesn't look good.

MARTIN: If your consumer and you're banking at Wells Fargo, wow do you feel good about having an account there. The CEO has said he is not resigning. He's not leaving.

BARTIROMO: No.

LEVIN: But should there be the question, should there be a call back of the $125 million that she's getting as she walks out the door. I don't think you reward people for being oblivious to things.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Especially since she's walking out with all that money.

Ken -- real quick. Final word from you in terms of what we should be looking at for potential bank fraud. You are former white-collar criminal FBI so tell us what we should be looking at.

SPRINGER: Well, there is a lot that needs to come out yet and probably in the next 24, we'll learn a lot more. But did they really -- we go in and open an account at our bank. Do you go in -- do you sign a signature card? Do you show forms of ID? I don't think that happened. I think they manipulated the system. But there is still the potential for fraud.

BARTIROMO: Because of this culture that you had to meet the sales targets.

SPRINGER: I think that's what's going to happen. I think the bigger fall fallout is going to be 5,300 people are without a job now. And they're going to be kind of potentially toxic trying to get jobs now as part of this. And what can they do?

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's a good point. You're going to have that on your resume. Yes, I just came from Wells Fargo and this is why I left.

SPRINGER: But in my experience -- I'm sorry, Maria -- is disclose it. Tell it upfront because you know, it's like Drexel back years, MF Global, people will get over it. Tell them you were part of it and move on.

BAKER: I think the key takeaway here is pay attention. You've got a personal responsibility. You open an account. You're dealing a financial institution. You've got a credit card or whatever it is, your statements arrive, you've got to pay attention. Otherwise things happen. And as you pointed out this is not the first time.

LEVIN: No one has a greater interest in your financial security than you do.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Bottom line.

MARTIN: These other people apparently.

BARTIROMO: Ken Springer, Adam Levin -- the book is "Swiped" -- thank you so much, sir, for joining us. Thank you very much Mr. Springer.

Coming up, another secretary of state and another scandal -- the shocking claims surrounding John Kerry's tenure.

Plus making the Second Amendment fashionable? The company giving new meeting to conceal and carry.

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Wednesday morning, everybody; welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Wednesday September 14. Here are your top stories, 7:30 a.m. on the East Coast: Breaking news moments ago, Bayer acquires Monsanto, deal is done; valued at $66 billion, that is $128 per share. This was first reported by our own Charlie Gasparino. (HEADLINES) (MARKET HEADLINES)

President Obama on the campaign trail now for the ailing Hillary Clinton. He used his time in Philadelphia yesterday to slam Donald Trump and his comments on Russian President Vladimir Putin.

(BEING VIDEO CLIP)

PRESIDENT BARACK OBAMA: Think about what's happened to the Republican Party. They used to be opposed to Russian and authoritarianism. Their nominee is out their praising a guy, saying he's a strong leader because he invades smaller countries, jails his opponents and when they interview him, ask him, well, why do you support this guy? Well, he's a strong guy. Look, he's got an 82-percent poll rating. Well, yes. So did - Saddam Hussein had a 90-percent poll rating.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Donald Trump responded to President Obama's attack on Twitter. He said, "Russia took Crimea during the so-called Obama years. Who wouldn't know this and why does Obama get a free pass."

Joining me right now is former U.S. Attorney General, Alberto Gonzalez. He is the author of the new book, "True Faith and Allegiance." Good morning, Judge. Good morning good to have you on the program. Thanks so much for joining us.

ALBERTO GONZALEZ, FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY GENERAL: Good morning; it's good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: So I've got to get your reaction to all of this talk about Russia. I mean, I seem to remember, quite clearly, it was President Obama who whispered in the ear of then Prime Minister Medvedev to say, or he was president at the time, I will have more flexibility, -- tell Vladimir Putin I will have more flexibility after the election. It seems there is a lot more ties between Clinton and Obama and Secretary Clinton than Donald Trump; correct me if I'm wrong.

GONZALEZ: I think you're right. We have to remember that we're in this sort of silly season right now. We're in a political campaign and there are going to be outrageous claims, honestly, made by both sides in order to win political points. But, obviously, we watch Russia very carefully. Obviously what they do around the world is something of great interest to us. Because they are a powerful nation, they can be helpful in dealing with certain problems that we need help with, for example in Syria. So the notion of having some kind of relationship with them is not a totally bad thing.

But, again, some of the comments yesterday from President Obama, I just chalk up we're in the political season.

BARTIROMO: I see; so have U.S.-Russian relations changed in the post-9/11 world, where the war on terror has been the top priority?

GONZALEZ: You know, I think (inaudible) depending on circumstances. I don't know that I would trust Russia implicitly. I think we need to -- they could be helpful, but obviously they will be doing some things that are in their best interest and not necessarily consistent with our best interest. So we just simply have to deal with them, I think, with that kind of mind set.

BARTIROMO: You are obviously were in a very important place during the beginning of the war on terror. You are defending that in your new book, "True Faith and Allegiance," in your new memoir. What are you trying to communicate, Judge?

GONZALEZ: Well, one thing I try to communicate is all the difficult decisions that President Bush had to make, and those of us who advised him; some of them are controversial, but one of the things I hope that readers come away with is how hard we worked to try to get it right, particularly in terms of the legal issues that arose. Many of these legal issues we had not seen since World War II. Some of the legal issues we had never seen before, such as how do you deal effectively and legally with a non-state actor.

So hopefully - you know, I don't shy away from any of the controversial issues. They are all in the book, beginning with Guantanamo, military commissions, enhanced interrogation techniques, electronic surveillance, it's all in there and hopefully the readers will have a better understanding of the reasons why these decisions were made and the rationale behind them.

BARTIROMO: So once we understand what took place and where we are right now, the next question is where are we going. We know that Donald Trump has talked about expanding the military, investing in the military and getting tougher. Hillary Clinton has said she wants to continue many of the policies of President Obama and that we need Middle Eastern friends help to actually take down ISIS. What is the right path going forward?

GONZALEZ: Well, I do believe we need Middle Eastern friends. This is not something that we can be successful alone. However, I do worry about the changing viewpoint about America around the world. I think we are America. We are the beacon of hope and democracy and we are expected to lead. I worry that we sort of stepped back from that. I think the common phrase is we are leading from behind. I just think that puts the United States in a very dangerous and precarious position.

I worry that we are less today than we were, say, on 9/11, 15 years ago. The threats have evolved and I think the United States needs to be very forceful, in terms of trying to influence outcomes overseas. I'm not suggesting we put troops on the ground, but I think we need to influence outcomes so we don't have outcomes that are contrary to our interests. So, I do worry about where we are today in foreign policy.

BARTIROMO: Have you made a decision to support a Donald Trump for president?

GONZALEZ: You know I'm a lifelong Republican. I hope to vote republican, but I'm an American first. I'm going to vote in terms of who I believe is best for America, best for me and for my family. Listen, we still have two months before the election. We have three presidential debates coming up. We've got time to make this decision, which is a very important one because it is a very dangerous time around the world for us. Also we have some serious domestic policy issues that we need to confront, like the deficit. So, I'm going to make a very informed decision. I encourage all of your viewers to do the same.

BARTIROMO: All right; so you want to watch these debates and you want to make sure you're solid before coming out publicly and endorsing the Republican candidate.

Let me ask you about what's going on on the Democratic side, Judge, because two witnesses, yesterday, at a House hearing on Hillary Clinton's email server pled The Fifth, yesterday, while a third failed to show. As a former attorney general, should a special prosecutor have been important to investigate Hillary's email server?

GONZALEZ: That's a difficult one for me to answer. I do know that the unfortunate conversation that occurred between Loretta Lynch and former President Bill Clinton at the airport. I think that was very unfortunate for the investigation, and, you know, some AG's may have taken that alone as a basis to appoint a special prosecutor because, in the end, it's not about the attorney general's involvement in the case that's important. What is important is that we have total confidence in the justice system, that it's going to be impartial in the way it conducts its investigation and in the decision it makes to move forward with the prosecution.

What I worry about what happened here is it appears as a result of that conversation Attorney General Lynch sort of stepped away entirely from this case and as a result it fell entirely to Jim Comey. Most of your viewers probably do not understand, the FBI reports to the Attorney General. The FBI Director reports to the Attorney General, and at the end of the day the FBI is response for investigations. They present whatever they find to the prosecutors and the prosecutors decide whether or not the case should move forward or not. It seems to me in this case it was sort of turned on its head and the investigator, Jim Comey, made the decision not to move forward with the prosecution; and that troubles me.

BARTIROMO: So, I mean, this is your, obviously, successor, Loretta Lynch. If you were sitting on your plane, as attorney general, and you got the message from your aide saying Bill Clinton wants to come up to the plane and talk to you, and you know that Hillary Clinton is going to be testifying or - not testifying but doing the interview with the FBI two days later, what would you have said to your aide? What should she have done? Should she have said, listen, I can't take the meeting? What would you have done?

GONZALEZ: Yes; I think that would've - look, at most you would go and say hello to the president as a matter of courtesy and say, you know, hello. Obviously because of the circumstances involving your wife we can't have a conversation; or it would have been totally appropriate to simply say - send back a message saying because of the circumstances involving your wife it wouldn't look good for either the wife or the attorney general to have any kind of conversation or meeting.

BARTIROMO: Right; or how about having an aide on the plane? Have you ever seen a situation where such an important position doesn't have someone taking notes? There was no one else on the plane.

GONZALEZ: Oh, I see what you're saying. Yes, that would not be unusual.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GONZALEZ: Typically - a private meeting like that would likely occur, where you would not have anybody on the plane.

BARTIROMO: I guess what I'm getting at, Judge, real quick, actually, have we become incredibly politicized? I mean, you see what happened with Loretta Lynch on the plane with Bill Clinton. Then you look at Jim Comey testifying with the FBI investigation. You look at the IRS targeting conservatives. What is going on?

GONZALEZ: Well, certainly there's the appearance of politicalization at the Department of Justice, and that is troubling to me and that's something that we should worry about and something the attorney general has an obligation to address because the Department should be viewed as a Department that operates without any kind of bias.

BARTIROMO: Right; Mr. Gonzalez, good to have you on the program. Judge, thank you so much for joining us.

GONZALEZ: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: We appreciate it very much. Congratulations on the book. Be sure to turn in tomorrow, Republican Vice Presidential Nominee, and Indiana Governor, Mike Pence my special guest. Back in a moment; stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Victims of the 2012 shooting at a Colorado movie theatre will not be on the hook for the major legal fee. Cheryl Casone with that story and other headlines now. Cheryl, good morning.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes, good morning, Maria. (HEADLINES)

BARTIROMO: All right, Cheryl; thank you so much. Coming up next, conceal and carry getting more stylish. How one company is helping women carry their firearm fashionably; back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Firearms and fashion, a combination that gunmakers have ignored this for decades as they focus their marketing on male customers. Background checks for gun purchases hit a record high in July and growing demand from women have created a new fashion industry. This is amazing. These products are designed for women, by women and they offer a stylish look and practical way for women to carry their guns.

Joining us right now is the owner of Nickel and Lace, Marilyn Smolenski. Marilyn, good to have you on the program. Thanks so much for joining us.

MARILYN SMOLENSKI, OWNER, NICKEL AND LACE: Thank you for having me. It's a pleasure.

BARTIROMO: How do you come up with this idea?

SMOLENSKI: Well, I was taking some classes with my husband back in 2011 and I just wasn't satisfied with any of the holsters that were on the market. They were all really geared towards men and men's bodies, not women's figures, so I made my own.

BARTIROMO: We actually have one of my colleagues wearing it this morning, I'm going to show it in a minute; but how did you get into the firearms accessory business to begin with? Did you see this demand out there that you felt women needed fashion and an opportunity to conceal and carry?

SMOLENSKI: Yes, ma'am; absolutely. At the time most of the manufactures were just making products smaller and turning them pink and that's how they were marketed to women. So there wasn't really anything for a woman's body and for our curves and I definitely saw something, a need there on the market for new items from women. So I spoke to some girlfriends that were in the fashion industry and also police officers and they were really excited and really encouraged me to go forward with it.

BARTIROMO: What kind of reception are you seeing right now at Nickel and Lace?

SMOLENSKI: Oh, just an outpouring of support. You know, when I first started it was kind of a taboo issue here in Chicago, as you can imagine --

BARTIROMO: Sure.

SMOLENSKI: -- this is where I'm based. But, you know, as time goes on or more people are being supportive of it, especially as the crime goes up in the city.

BARTIROMO: So tell us what we need to know to actually wear one of these things. What are the particulars and how does it work?

SMOLENSKI: So the particulars are that this is a shapewear based foundation, so it goes underneath your clothing, and it has special use pockets on either side, so it's ambidextrous. It's meant for a cross body draw for a subcompact firearm. So, for a smaller firearm, which does hide better on a woman's body. If you're not going to use of firearm, in places like Chicago you can't carry everywhere, you can also carry your cellphone, your keys, your id. It's also what I did when I was in Europe. I was carrying different items so I wouldn't get, let's say, pickpocketed on the subway.

BARTIROMO: That's a different -

SMOLENSKI: There is a lot of different functionalities to it.

BARTIROMO: It has different uses. Morgan Ortagus, who is with us this morning, has it on. Let's take a look. Morgan, how does it feel?

MORGAN ORTAGUS, NATIONAL CO-CHAIR, MAVERICK PAC: I love the fact that it's shapewear. We were just saying backstage you could wear this underneath a blazer and then you could see the sides, right there, where the -

BARTIROMO: Gun would go.

ORTAGUS: -- gun, your cellphone, whatever, right here. So, yes, it feels great.

BARTIROMO: You say it feels like it's a shaper. You like it.

ORTAGUS: It does feel like shapewear. I might keep it on for the rest of the show.

[Laughter]

SMOLENSKI: Well you can keep it. You can have it if you love it. It's yours.

BARTIROMO: What is the next for Nickel and Lace? Are you planning to expand this brand -

SMOLENSKI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- or are you going to stay with firearms?

SMOLENSKI: You know what, we are going to expand to a lot of things but most things are going to incorporate firearms. We're working on outerwear vest at the moment, and it will have conceal carry pockets on the inside of a fashion vest, either faux fur or suede. We're also working on a running belly band for runners, as well as another shape wear but with some lace and added features to it. So we are just plowing away with research and development and making our products better and more useful for women.

BARTIROMO: Well, no doubt, being based in Chicago you've seen what has gone on there, in terms of the murders in the violence.

SMOLENSKI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So it must be resonating in Chicago? People want to protect themselves.

SMOLENSKI: It really is. Correct. Correct. You know, my sales were more out of state before, but now, with the rise in crime, I am seeing an increase in sales, as well, here.

BARTIROMO: Marilyn, we'll be watching the developments. Thanks so much for joining us.

SMOLENSKI: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Marilyn Smolenski there joining us; Nickel and Lace. And, Morgan, you may wear this for the rest of the show?

ORTAGUS: Listen, you know, shape wear and pistols? God Bless America.

BARTIROMO: There you go; coming up, the fast food wars are heating up. We tried the Burger King Cheetos Chicken fries but that's not all the industries doing to being in customers. We'll talk to the former Young Brown's founder, David Novak in the next hour, "Mornings with Maria." Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Good Wednesday morning everybody. Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Wednesday, September 14. Here are your top stories, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Hillary Clinton off the campaign trail for a third straight day but the questions over her private e-mail server are looming large during a congressional hearing. And Donald Trump is on the attack on it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: This attitude of arrogance that explains why Hillary Clinton made 13 phones disappear including with a hammer, so the FBI couldn't see them. And why she bleached her e-mails after a congressional subpoena -- that's after the subpoena came.

Now the people who destroyed the e-mails are all pleading the Fifth Amendment in front of Congress. Anyone watching today's hearing in Congress knows that Hillary Clinton's actions are far more corrupt.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The latest on the race to the White House coming up.

Plus protecting your finances. The Wells Fargo scandal raising questions for bank customers across the country. What you need to know to keep your money safe -- coming up.

A rough start for Apple's latest software upgrade -- the update causing major problems for users sparking social media outrage. We'll bring it to you.

And taking the smart home to a new level. Amazon teams up with General Electric so you can remotely preheat your oven and start your laundry.

Concealed carry hits the runway. We have a look at one company that's making it easier for women to carry their weapons. Yes.

In markets, futures edging higher this morning -- another big move yesterday and we are extending that move. Take a look. The markets are expected to open fractionally better on the session today.

In Europe the tone was set higher, led by a rebound in the price of oil. FT 100 up two-thirds of a percent now.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board. And the Kospi in Korea closed for a holiday.

We've got all of those stories coming up this hour.

And joining me to talk about it Maverick PAC national co-chair Morgan Ortagus; Kingsview Asset Management Scott Martin; and former CIA operative and Diligence president, Mike Baker.

Wow, what a story on Google just there.

MIKE BAKER, FORMER CIA OPERATIVE: It's incredible. When you do think about what could be happening. And this is just the tip of the iceberg. This is just saying that Google is impacting your searches on Hillary Clinton.

Then you think, well, are they also impacting your searches on issues that, you know, favor Hillary Clinton's point of view. I mean this thing just goes on and on.

BARTIROMO: Like the refugee crisis.

BAKER: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Like health care.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, MAVERICK PAC: It's no surprise, Maria, that there's big mistrust of everything in big government and big institutions and big tech. That's why were seeing this play out in this election cycle. People have a fundamental lack of trust in the institutions and organizations and corporations that seem to control our lives.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're going to talk all about that.

SCOTT MARTIN, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: They control your lives and Google is in home, it's on your smart phone, it's on your tablet.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And the problem is you don't know it. You don't realize but you could be actually being taken advantage of.

We've got a can't-miss lineup this hour. Stay with us. We are about to speak with former U.S. Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, we will ask him his opinion on this; former Hillary Clinton presidential campaign senior adviser Mark Penn is with us; and former Yum Brands chairman and CEO David Novak stops by as well.

Meanwhile outrage on Capitol Hill this morning. Three former Clinton workers refusing to testify before a congressional oversight committee yesterday regarding the Democratic nominee's use of a private server. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: On the advice of counsel I respectfully decline to answer and observe my Fifth Amendment privilege.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I respectfully decline to answer and observe my Fifth Amendment constitutional privilege.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I have no opening statement.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Former Bill Clinton aide, Justin Cooper also took the stand but he actually answered questions. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JASON CHAFFETZ (R), UTAH: Did you have a security clearance at that time?

JUSTIN COOPER, FORMER BILL CLINTON AIDE: No I did not have a security clearance.

CHAFFETZ: After you left the White House early in -- when did you leave the White House?

COOPER: 2001.

CHAFFETZ: 2001. Did you ever have a security clearance at any level after that?

COOPER: No, I did not have a security clearance.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Was your purpose in destroying the old Blackberry device ever to hide Secretary Clinton's e-mails from being saved or disclosed from federal records laws.

COOPER: Congresswoman, no. It's not in any way to destroy or hide any information at all. I was going out of my way to preserve all of the information that was on those devices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Right. That's why he used a hammer to destroy the device to save it.

Joining me right now is a member of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, Florida Congressman John Mica. Congressman -- good to have you on the program. Thanks very much for joining us.

REP. JOHN MICA (R), FLORIDA: Good to be with you. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Your takeaway from the happenings yesterday.

MICA: Well, I think they're trying to run the clock out. We saw one witness not show up, thumb his nose at Congress, two that took the Fifth Amendment and the other we learned some information from -- this has been a cat and mouse game from the beginning.

We started with Benghazi trying to find out what took place, who did what and we just keep getting the stall and not the information that Congress is entitled to.

BARTIROMO: So I mean does this just mean you are powerless in this regard? I mean what are you going to do? One guy, Pagliano, decides it's just not imp. I'm not showing up. He blows it off. You have the other two not revealing anything. And then Justin Cooper, no pushback on the fact that he says oh no, I was trying to preserve information. But we know he's the guy with the hammer. What happens now -- Congressman?

BARTIROMO: So tell us what we need to know to actually wear one of these things. What are the particulars and how does it work?

SMOLENSKI: So the particulars are that this is a shapewear based foundation, so it goes underneath your clothing, and it has special use pockets on either side, so it's ambidextrous. It's meant for a cross body draw for a subcompact firearm. So, for a smaller firearm, which does hide better on a woman's body. If you're not going to use of firearm, in places like Chicago you can't carry everywhere, you can also carry your cellphone, your keys, your id. It's also what I did when I was in Europe. I was carrying different items so I wouldn't get, let's say, pickpocketed on the subway.

BARTIROMO: That's a different -

SMOLENSKI: There is a lot of different functionalities to it.

BARTIROMO: It has different uses. Morgan Ortagus, who is with us this morning, has it on. Let's take a look. Morgan, how does it feel?

MORGAN ORTAGUS, NATIONAL CO-CHAIR, MAVERICK PAC: I love the fact that it's shapewear. We were just saying backstage you could wear this underneath a blazer and then you could see the sides, right there, where the -

BARTIROMO: Gun would go.

ORTAGUS: -- gun, your cellphone, whatever, right here. So, yes, it feels great.

BARTIROMO: You say it feels like it's a shaper. You like it.

ORTAGUS: It does feel like shapewear. I might keep it on for the rest of the show.

[Laughter]

SMOLENSKI: Well you can keep it. You can have it if you love it. It's yours.

BARTIROMO: What is the next for Nickel and Lace? Are you planning to expand this brand -

SMOLENSKI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- or are you going to stay with firearms?

SMOLENSKI: You know what, we are going to expand to a lot of things but most things are going to incorporate firearms. We're working on outerwear vest at the moment, and it will have conceal carry pockets on the inside of a fashion vest, either faux fur or suede. We're also working on a running belly band for runners, as well as another shape wear but with some lace and added features to it. So we are just plowing away with research and development and making our products better and more useful for women.

BARTIROMO: Well, no doubt, being based in Chicago you've seen what has gone on there, in terms of the murders in the violence.

SMOLENSKI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So it must be resonating in Chicago? People want to protect themselves.

SMOLENSKI: It really is. Correct. Correct. You know, my sales were more out of state before, but now, with the rise in crime, I am seeing an increase in sales, as well, here.

BARTIROMO: Marilyn, we'll be watching the developments. Thanks so much for joining us.

SMOLENSKI: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Marilyn Smolenski there joining us; Nickel and Lace. And, Morgan, you may wear this for the rest of the show?

ORTAGUS: Listen, you know, shape wear and pistols? God Bless America.

BARTIROMO: There you go; coming up, the fast food wars are heating up. We tried the Burger King Cheetos Chicken fries but that's not all the industries doing to being in customers. We'll talk to the former Young Brown's founder, David Novak in the next hour, "Mornings with Maria." Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back; good Wednesday morning, everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, September 14. Your top stories right now, 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast: (HEADLINES).

urn:contentItem:5KPS-81B1-DXH2-651X-00000-00Pleading the Fifth; Burger King Cheetos Chicken Fries; Bayer Buys Monsanto; Wells Fargo CEO Blames Employees; Bayer Acquires Monsanto; President Obama Hits Campaign Trail for Hillary Clinton; Former AG Alberto Gonzalez Relseas New Memoir2016-09-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:45ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMike Baker, Morgan Ortagus; Alberto Gonzalez; Marilyn Smolenzki, Scott Martin, John Mica, Ken Springer, Adam LevinNEWSDomestic091402cb.231Pleading the Fifth; Burger King Cheetos Chicken Fries; Bayer Buys Monsanto; Wells Fargo CEO Blames Employees; Bayer Acquires Monsanto; President Obama Hits Campaign Trail for Hillary Clinton; Former AG Alberto Gonzalez Relseas New MemoirMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Good Wednesday morning everybody. Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Wednesday, September 14. Here are your top stories, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Hillary Clinton off the campaign trail for a third straight day but the questions over her private e-mail server are looming large during a congressional hearing. And Donald Trump is on the attack on it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: This attitude of arrogance that explains why Hillary Clinton made 13 phones disappear including with a hammer, so the FBI couldn't see them. And why she bleached her e-mails after a congressional subpoena -- that's after the subpoena came.

Now the people who destroyed the e-mails are all pleading the Fifth Amendment in front of Congress. Anyone watching today's hearing in Congress knows that Hillary Clinton's actions are far more corrupt.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The latest on the race to the White House coming up.

Plus protecting your finances. The Wells Fargo scandal raising questions for bank customers across the country. What you need to know to keep your money safe -- coming up.

A rough start for Apple's latest software upgrade -- the update causing major problems for users sparking social media outrage. We'll bring it to you.

And taking the smart home to a new level. Amazon teams up with General Electric so you can remotely preheat your oven and start your laundry.

Concealed carry hits the runway. We have a look at one company that's making it easier for women to carry their weapons. Yes.

In markets, futures edging higher this morning -- another big move yesterday and we are extending that move. Take a look. The markets are expected to open fractionally better on the session today.

In Europe the tone was set higher, led by a rebound in the price of oil. FT 100 up two-thirds of a percent now.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board. And the Kospi in Korea closed for a holiday.

We've got all of those stories coming up this hour.

And joining me to talk about it Maverick PAC national co-chair Morgan Ortagus; Kingsview Asset Management Scott Martin; and former CIA operative and Diligence president, Mike Baker.

Wow, what a story on Google just there.

MIKE BAKER, FORMER CIA OPERATIVE: It's incredible. When you do think about what could be happening. And this is just the tip of the iceberg. This is just saying that Google is impacting your searches on Hillary Clinton.

Then you think, well, are they also impacting your searches on issues that, you know, favor Hillary Clinton's point of view. I mean this thing just goes on and on.

BARTIROMO: Like the refugee crisis.

BAKER: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Like health care.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, MAVERICK PAC: It's no surprise, Maria, that there's big mistrust of everything in big government and big institutions and big tech. That's why were seeing this play out in this election cycle. People have a fundamental lack of trust in the institutions and organizations and corporations that seem to control our lives.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're going to talk all about that.

SCOTT MARTIN, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: They control your lives and Google is in home, it's on your smart phone, it's on your tablet.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And the problem is you don't know it. You don't realize but you could be actually being taken advantage of.

We've got a can't-miss lineup this hour. Stay with us. We are about to speak with former U.S. Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, we will ask him his opinion on this; former Hillary Clinton presidential campaign senior adviser Mark Penn is with us; and former Yum Brands chairman and CEO David Novak stops by as well.

Meanwhile outrage on Capitol Hill this morning. Three former Clinton workers refusing to testify before a congressional oversight committee yesterday regarding the Democratic nominee's use of a private server. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: On the advice of counsel I respectfully decline to answer and observe my Fifth Amendment privilege.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I respectfully decline to answer and observe my Fifth Amendment constitutional privilege.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I have no opening statement.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Former Bill Clinton aide, Justin Cooper also took the stand but he actually answered questions. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JASON CHAFFETZ (R), UTAH: Did you have a security clearance at that time?

JUSTIN COOPER, FORMER BILL CLINTON AIDE: No I did not have a security clearance.

CHAFFETZ: After you left the White House early in -- when did you leave the White House?

COOPER: 2001.

CHAFFETZ: 2001. Did you ever have a security clearance at any level after that?

COOPER: No, I did not have a security clearance.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Was your purpose in destroying the old Blackberry device ever to hide Secretary Clinton's e-mails from being saved or disclosed from federal records laws.

COOPER: Congresswoman, no. It's not in any way to destroy or hide any information at all. I was going out of my way to preserve all of the information that was on those devices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Right. That's why he used a hammer to destroy the device to save it.

Joining me right now is a member of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, Florida Congressman John Mica. Congressman -- good to have you on the program. Thanks very much for joining us.

REP. JOHN MICA (R), FLORIDA: Good to be with you. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Your takeaway from the happenings yesterday.

MICA: Well, I think they're trying to run the clock out. We saw one witness not show up, thumb his nose at Congress, two that took the Fifth Amendment and the other we learned some information from -- this has been a cat and mouse game from the beginning.

We started with Benghazi trying to find out what took place, who did what and we just keep getting the stall and not the information that Congress is entitled to.

BARTIROMO: So I mean does this just mean you are powerless in this regard? I mean what are you going to do? One guy, Pagliano, decides it's just not imp. I'm not showing up. He blows it off. You have the other two not revealing anything. And then Justin Cooper, no pushback on the fact that he says oh no, I was trying to preserve information. But we know he's the guy with the hammer. What happens now -- Congressman?

MICA: Again, we have to follow the law and the rules of procedure. Pagliano did not show up. He can be held as I questioned the chairman in attempt of Congress. A referral would then go to the Department of Justice and there could be proceedings, criminal proceeding possibly against him.

Right now were looking at the options. I don't know if the chairman will give him another opportunity to come forward. I don't know whether there are other remedies from a legal standpoint we have.

But again, you see a stalling game. This guy played the same thing with the FBI. We think he was granted immunity, we don't know to what extent. But he should have at least showed up if he wanted to exercise his right like the other two did, he could take the Fifth Amendment before us.

But again this is just a continuum of stalling; failing to give Congress the information we are entitled to. We are entitled to conduct a thorough investigation. Our committee has charge over all matters for investigations under the House of Representatives. And they are thwarting that process.

BARTIROMO: Right. Morgan.

ORTAGUS: Good morning -- Congressman. Hillary Clinton had gotten a pass by the FBI. We know this already. But can you tell me what is going on with her top aides? Are you still investigating them in Congress? We saw last week on the show that immunity was granted to yet another person on the server even though we thought the investigation was closed.

What is going on with the people who are actually in control of this information of this e-mail? We haven't really heard and I think the American people would like to know what is happening to those people in power.

MICA: Well, we heard from one witness a little bit of information. We are trying to gather all the facts because you can't proceed without the facts. Some information we did learn and we seized from some of the FBI 302s.

It appears that people like Cheryl Mills, one of the aides to the secretary possibly ordered some of the destruction of the (inaudible) that should have been preserved. We have a requirement to preserve records even though she had them on a private server. She had classified information and other information that wasn't properly turned over and may have been destroyed.

So we're trying to find out what took place. And every time we turn to another witness, we find out there is more. When they talk to the FBI they suddenly dump new found e-mails. It is a stall to try to run out the clock. And we are, I think entitled to complete the investigation in a proper and thorough manner.

BARTIROMO: Of course. Here's Mike Baker.

BAKER: Yes. Congressman -- good morning. There used to be a sense that there were consequences for action. And I think there is a frustration out there in the American public that perhaps things just go to the Hill and die nowadays whether it's the Benghazi investigation or any other investigation regardless of where on the political spectrum it stands.

BARTIROMO: IRS.

BAKER: Yes -- IRS. What is your timeframe for this particular situation where Brian Pagliano ignores a subpoena, doesn't show up. You know, I realize you have to follow procedures but you're also Congress. And do you have the ability to move at your own pace here and what will your timeframe be to deal with that?

MICA: Well, unlike some here, we do comply with the constitution with the constraints imposed on us. Even Congress has constraints. So we can't go and prosecute. Now we have to see again what was done in contravention of the law and the rules, take the steps that are allowed under the law. Unfortunately we have a Department of Justice whether it's been Loretta Lynch or Holder that are non-responsive and turned a blind eye.

We have a very difficult situation, a very difficult job. But, you know, this is kind of like that old law enforcement serial on TV. All we want are the facts ma'am. And our job is to get the facts for the public and then take action. But we have to do that.

If they want to be lawless our side of the aisle is not going to be. We want to comply with the law and the proper procedures.

BARTIROMO: But when you say they're trying to, you know, wipe the clock out, you know, let the clock run out does that mean that they're going to just let the clock run out until the end of the couple of months and let the election happen and then they're hoping Hillary Clinton wins and then it just dies and goes away because she's president. Is that what you're saying?

MICA: Well, again, they already have control of the Department of Justice. It appears the FBI may have been compromised from there. And it's much disappointing with the Director Comey who has had a fairly good reputation not to give us the information. You may recall during the hearings I said the secretary and her interview recorded. No. Do you have any information from that? Yes we have the 302s. We still don't have the 302s from that and some have been kept from us.

They are playing a cat and mouse game whether it's the Department of Justice, now the FBI. It's a very sad time for our judicial system and the process that should move forward in an orderly manner under the constitution laws of the United States.

BARTIROMO: Yes. What a disgrace for the American people if all of these agencies have become compromised and politicized at this point.

Congressman -- thanks very much for your insights. We appreciate this.

MICA: Good to be with you. We will continue this.

BARTIROMO: And so will we. John Mica -- joining us.

Go ahead Mike Baker.

BAKER: Yes. I think that was very interesting what he just said. It was almost a throwaway comment where he said that the FBI may have been compromised as well. What I would say is I don't know Director Comey's motivation for his decision that he made recently. I will say this. I've had the good fortune of working with the FBI over the years including recently and I know some of those folks. The agents there at the FBI, they are not compromised. This is not an issue regarding the agents or the FBI.

This is -- and again, not knowing what Director Comey's concerns are -- DOJ, is it political? Of course. But the FBI -- those folks do their job and investigate.

BARTIROMO: I know some FBI agents, too and I agree with you. They are --

MARTIN: Look at all the evidence we dug out.

BAKER: Right.

BARTIROMO: What happened to Jim Comey?

BAKER: You know what, it's a question I don't know where we're going to get an answer to. And it surprised a lot of people. You remember the talk in Washington was all before his decision. He's a great. He's completely nonpartisan. He is the most nonpartisan person there.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But the interview was not recorded. The interview wasn't on the record. Basically her lawyers told the FBI look, if you record this she's not showing up.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Ok, we won't record.

ORTAGUS: And he let Loretta Lynch off the hook two days after she met on a private plane with Bill Clinton for 30 minutes.

BAKER: Right.

BARTIROMO: Explain that to us.

ORTAGUS: It's as political as it gets.

BARTIROMO: We're going to talk about this tomorrow as well when we have a special guest. Governor Mike Pence will join us tomorrow, 8:30 a.m. Eastern right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Don't miss our special interview tomorrow coming up with Governor Mike Pence.

Still to come: as Hillary rests, President Obama is on the attack. The details as he hits the campaign trail. We'll tell you the reception that the President got as he stumps for Hillary.

Plus move over buffalo. We are testing Burger King's new Cheetos chicken. How's that for breakfast?

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Well, the hacker known as Guccifer 2.0 releasing more DNC documents.

Cheryl Casone with that and the headlines now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Maria.

Well, Guccifer 2.0 disclosed the documents at a cyber security conference in London yesterday. They include the Democratic National Committee's finances and network infrastructure. Among them Democratic vice presidential candidate Tim Kaine cell phone number and the contact information for several top White House officials. U.S. intelligence officials suspect Russian involvement.

Well, if you upgraded your Apple device to the latest IOS software yesterday and you didn't have a problem. You were one of the lucky ones. Some people were hit by a major bug that left their devices temporarily useless.

There are reports that some of the upgrades resulted in a so-called bricked iPhone or iPad. Basically when that happens your device has a black screen and access is totally blocked. Those unlucky people had to plug the devices into their computers, connect to iTunes and restore their devices completely. This is why you should always backup your phone, folks. Apple acknowledging the problem; they later did say that they had resolved it.

And finally, we first told you about this new item from Burger King yesterday, Cheetos Chicken fries. But they're out today. You have to eat lunch at some point right. So before we dive into them on set because, of course, I brought them, we should tell you that the fries are made with all white meat chicken. They are covered in a flavored breading that includes crushed up Cheetos. Nine-piece order, $2.89 Maria and for all of you watching your waistlines one order is 280 calories.

And I brought them to try because I think we should try things like this.

BARTIROMO: I'm supposed to believe that this is 280 calories.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: 280 calories -- would I lie to you Maria Bartiromo.

BARTIROMO: If only our viewers can smell what I smell on this set right now -- wow.

MARTIN: What's the calorie count? Is the calorie count per the order?

BARTIROMO: This is 280 calories.

CASONE: Yes, ma'am.

ORTAGUS: You can taste the Cheetos.

CASONE: You can taste the Cheetos?

ORTAGUS: I'm from Florida, ma'am. We love our junk food. The taste is great.

BARTIROMO: Can you taste any chicken?

MARTIN: This is the breakfast of champions, baby.

BARTIROMO: Just tasty.

MARTIN: If you have this with the Red Bull and Vodka in the morning your day is set.

(CROSSTALK)

BAKER: I'll tell you what, that's the breakfast of champions right there.

BARTIROMO: While you're enjoying your breakfast, ladies and gentlemen, let me tell you we do have breaking news.

Bayer is acquiring Monsanto-- the deal is done, Scott Martin as we expected.

MARTIN: Have fun with the regulators on that one. I mean they blocked so many of this, this year. It's good to see this being done. What's funny about this deal too, Maria, agriculture.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MARTIN: Agriculture prices have been falling through the floor. So it's interesting to see these two companies get together.

urn:contentItem:5VV9-X7K1-JBJ7-N0WX-00000-00'Plea for level playing field': Telstra boss calls for crackdown on tech giants2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:45ZLexisNexis'Plea for level playing field': Telstra boss calls for crackdown on tech giantsJennifer Duke

Telstra CEO Andy Penn has called on the government to crackdown on the big tech giants to level the playing field for telecommunications companies and broadcasters.

Telstra chief executive Andy Penn has called on the government to crackdown on the global technology giants to level the playing field for telecommunications companies and broadcasters in Australia.

Mr Penn pushed for the "same regulations for the same service regardless of the origins and industry of the provider" in a speech on Tuesday morning at the annual telco industry event, CommsDay Summit.

Currently, telco and broadcast licences require companies to stick to rules that impose tough conditions, like universal services obligations (that require certain services to be made available for all Australians) and content regulations. This legislation does not apply to social media companies.

Mr Penn said many of the services provided by Telstra, such as some forms of messaging, are also provided by over-the-top companies "outside of our regulatory framework".

"Services such as Viber or WhatsApp [owned by Facebook] do not have universal services or terminating obligations," he said. "This is not a criticism of those companies it is just a plea for a more level playing field when it comes to regulation.

"I do not envy policymakers and regulators here," Mr Penn said.

"But the problem is technology is moving fast and the reality is sometimes our regulatory environment can struggle to keep pace," he said.

He pointed to the Christchurch massacre in March, which was livestreamed on Facebook by the alleged gunman, and the decision of internet service providers to block websites sharing the footage. The government has   imposed new legislation on companies, including social media and forums, that threatens jail time and hefty fines for those who do not remove objectionable content in a reasonable timeframe.

"I strongly believe that was the right thing to do. I would make exactly the same decision again today in the same circumstances," he said.

"My layman's view is that broadcasting is broadcasting and that the rules and norms that apply around content must be consistent regardless of the platform from which the content is broadcast.

"There is no reason why social platforms should be in a different category, so I applaud the government for recognising that."

Mr Penn said it was "better" to have accepted frameworks in place to be able to target websites "appropriately".

The major telcos and social media companies are currently involved in a government-led taskforce to create an emergency response plan should terrorist action involving livestream content or other violent footage be widely shared online.

urn:contentItem:5YWD-P181-JDJN-64GG-00000-00Plea for solidarity to fight global 'tsunami of hate'2020-05-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:45ZLexisNexisPlea for solidarity to fight global 'tsunami of hate'China Daily Global

By Harvey Morris | China Daily Global | Updated: 2020-05-12 10:17

United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres is seen on a video screen. [Photo/Agencies]

The world is facing a parallel threat alongside the COVID-19 crisis, according to United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, who warned of a "tsunami of hate" that has accompanied the spread of the virus.

In a global appeal in which the UN chief called for international solidarity, he lamented that "the pandemic continues to unleash a tsunami of hate and xenophobia, scapegoating and scare-mongering".

When Beijing was still tackling the peak of its own health crisis, people of Chinese origin faced physical and verbal abuse in a number of Western countries from those who linked them to the spread of the novel coronavirus.

Since then, such prejudice has spread like the virus to attack any minority that excites the hatred of the xenophobes－migrants, refugees, Muslims, Jews and even the elderly.

Although the so-called alt-right has been at the forefront of spreading anti-minority smears online, some politicians have contributed to fuelling the phenomenon.

At a time when experts were warning against labeling the new disease "the China virus", United States President Donald Trump did just that, publicly using the phrase more than 20 times in the second half of March.

Since then the pandemic has provoked a bonanza of misinformation from online conspiracy theorists, who have targeted not just minorities but also individuals, such as philanthropists George Soros and Bill Gates.

In a recent broadcast, the far-right, pro-Trump One America News Network linked Soros, Gates, the "deep state" and China to a global conspiracy to establish sweeping population control－and even threw former US president Bill Clinton into the mix for good measure.

More of the same can no doubt be anticipated in a febrile US election year in which the administration appears focused on blaming everyone except itself for the failings of the pandemic response.

The UN's Guterres, in his Friday appeal, said all societies needed to strengthen their immunity to the virus of hate. And, without naming names, he called on politicians "to show solidarity with all members of their societies and build and reinforce social cohesion".

In the UK, where police recorded a sharp increase in hate crimes against Chinese people as the COVID-19 outbreak took hold, online agitators have aired fake videos that appear to show British Muslims breaking lockdown regulations by attending mosques.

In France, one far-right website listed the names of Jewish experts in charge of the country's health system and denounced the efforts of a Jewish politician to ease the pressure on French prisons as a plot to "liberate 7,000 black and Arab cut-throats".

In Germany meanwhile, experts warned against the rise of what they called "pandemic populism" in which online conspiracists sought to link the health crisis to a range of their favorite political targets. The danger was that even the most outlandish claims could seep into the mainstream media or be spread by unwitting celebrities.

The UN's World Health Organization, already fully occupied with tackling the global response to COVID-19, has complained of an "infodemic "swirling across society.

Despite the concerns the conspiracy phenomenon is provoking among these experts and officials already working overtime to cope with the crisis, there are some signs of a fightback.

In Texas, the San Antonio City Council unanimously passed a resolution denouncing bigotry, anti-Semitism, crimes against Asian Americans and hate speech amid the pandemic.

On a global level, the UN is launching a new communications initiative "based on science, solutions and solidarity to fight misinformation".

"Fear, uncertainty, and the proliferation of fake news have the potential to weaken the national and global response to the virus, bolster nativist narratives and provide opportunities for those who may seek to exploit this moment to deepen social divisions," said Melissa Fleming, UN under-secretary-general for Global Communications, who is leading the campaign.

The campaign involves providing authoritative scientific information to counter myths and partnering with the big tech companies to get those messages online. It will also work more closely with journalists to combat falsehoods, fabrications and misinformation.

The UN and national authorities clearly hope the still, small voice of common sense can overcome the fog horn of nonsense, intentional or otherwise, that threatens to dominate the current debate.

Let us hope it is so. The world can deal with a physical pandemic, but the effort will be that much greater if it has to handle an informational one at the same time.

Harvey Morris is a senior media consultant for China Daily UK
